title: Rapid Method for Estimating Polyhydroxybutyrate Accumulation in Bacteria Using Sodium Hypochlorite
abstract: This protocol outlines the use of the previously described sodium hypochlorite extraction method for estimating the accumulation of polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) in bacteria. Sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) is widely used for PHB extraction as it oxidizes most components of the cells except PHB. We assessed the feasibility of using NaClO extraction for the estimation of PHB accumulation in bacterial cells (expressed as a percentage w/w). This allowed us to use a simple spectrophotometric measurement of the turbidity of the PHB extracted by NaClO as a semiquantitative estimation of PHB accumulation in the marine microorganisms Halomonas titanicae KHS3, Alteromonas sp., and Cobetia sp. However, this fast and easy protocol could be used for any bacterial species as long as some details are considered. This estimation exhibited a good correlation with the accumulation measured as dry cell weight or even with the accumulation measured by crotonic acid and HPLC quantifications. The key advantage of this protocol is how fast it allows an estimation of PHB accumulation in Halomonas, Alteromonas, and Cobetia cultures (results are available in 50 min ), enabling the identification of the appropriate moment to harvest cells for further extraction, polymer characterization, and accurate quantification using more reliable and time-consuming methods. This protocol is very useful during bacterial cultivation for a quick evaluation of PHA accumulation without requiring (i) large volumes of cultures, (ii) a long time for analysis compared to dry cell weight, (iii) preparation of standard curves with sulfuric acid hydrolysis for crotonic acid quantification, or (iv) specific equipment and/or technical services for HPLC quantification.
problem: Traditional methods for estimating polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) accumulation in bacteria are time-consuming, require specialized equipment, and involve complex procedures, making it challenging to monitor PHB production efficiently during bacterial cultivation.
method: The protocol employs sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) to selectively oxidize cellular components, leaving PHB intact, and uses spectrophotometric measurement of PHB turbidity for semi-quantitative estimation.
innovation: The method is rapid (results in 50 minutes), requires minimal sample volume, eliminates the need for specialized equipment or standard curve preparation, and exhibits good correlation with established quantification methods like dry cell weight and HPLC.
application: Initially validated for marine bacteria (Halomonas, Alteromonas, and Cobetia), the protocol is adaptable to other bacterial species and is particularly useful for quick PHB accumulation monitoring during cultivation, aiding in determining optimal harvest times.

# Biological materials

1.  Environmental strains isolated from seawater and identified as Halomonas titanicae KHS3, Alteromonas sp., and Cobetia sp.

# Reagents

6. Ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl_36H_2O) ) (Fluka, catalog number: 44944)
7. Sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) 5.5% (w/v) commercially available household bleach *

9. Glycerol (Gly) (BioPack, catalog number: 1620.08)
10. Distilled water
11. Bacteriological agar (Oxoid, catalog number: LP0011)

*Note: Store at room temperature. Undiluted household bleach has a shelf life of six months to one year;
afterward, it degrades and loses oxidative activity.

# Solutions

1. H1 minimal medium (see Recipes)
2. Yeast extract 10% (YE) (see Recipes)
3. Glycerol 75% (Gly) (see Recipes)

# Recipes

Note: All solutions must be autoclaved before use.

()
*Add after autoclaving.

Note: Different carbon sources are used depending on the desired culture condition: for PHB accumulation condition, 3% glycerol; for non-PHB accumulation condition, 0.25% yeast extract. To prepare plates, add I.5% bacteriological agar to the medium. This protocol utilizes marine halotolerant bacteria, which are cultivated in H1 minimal medium. If non-halotolerant bacteria are used, appropriate media must be prepared.

Note: For the cell suspension solution when using halophilic or halotolerant microorganisms. Otherwise, use a solution with the appropriate composition (saline/buffer solution similar to the growth medium).

Cite as: Redersdorff, I.E. et al. (2024). Rapid Method for Estimating Polyhydroxybutyrate Accumulation in Bacteria Using Sodium Hypochlorite. Bio-protocol 14(23): e5130. DOI: 10.21769/BioProtoc.5130.

1.title: Bacterial Growth Under Accumulation and No-Accumulation Conditions

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Spread a fresh H1 minimal medium plus 0.25% yeast extract plate of H. titanicae or the desired microorganism.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Incubate at the appropriate temperature and time.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Start a fresh 3mL overnight culture inoculated from the fresh plate.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Incubate at the appropriate temperature and time.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Inoculate a 50~mL culture in a 250~mL flask with an initial OD_600nm of approximately 0.05.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Use either accumulation medium (H1 medium with 3% glycerol) or non-accumulation medium (H1 medium with 0.25% yeast extract).
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.1: Monitor cell growth by measuring optical density (OD_600nm) using 1 mL of sample.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Collect samples at desired intervals to evaluate PHB accumulation.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Determine OD_600nm of the culture to be evaluated.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Harvest an appropriate volume of culture based on the OD_600nm values.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Calculate the required volume using the formula: (final volume desired of cell suspension) × (final desired OD_600nm) = (culture volume needed) × (OD_600nm of culture)
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Centrifuge at 9,700×g for 5~min to pellet the cells.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Remove the supernatant and gently withdraw the residue with a P200 pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Resuspend the cell pellet in 2~mL of 2% NaCl solution or alternative solutions based on bacterial strain requirements.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.1: Divide the cell suspension into two fractions, each of 700~uL, in microcentrifuge tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2: Label the tubes as dH2O and NaClO.
hierarchical_protocol.2.6.1: Add 150~uL of distilled water to the tube labeled dH2O.
hierarchical_protocol.2.6.2: Add 150~uL of sodium hypochlorite from a 5.5% (w/v) stock solution to the tube labeled NaClO.
hierarchical_protocol.2.8.1: Measure the OD_600nm for each tube within 15min after completion of incubation.
hierarchical_protocol.2.9.1: Estimate the percentage of accumulated PHA using the formula described in the Data analysis section.

title: Culture and Characterization of Differentiated Airway Organoids from Fetal Mouse Lung Proximal Progenitors
abstract: Developing a physiologically relevant in vitro model of the respiratory epithelium is critical for understanding lung development and respiratory diseases. Here, we describe a detailed protocol in which the fetal mouse proximal epithelial progenitors were differentiated into 3D airway organoids, which contain terminal-differentiated ciliated cells and basal stem cells. These differentiated airway organoids could constitute an excellent experimental model to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of airway development and epithelial cell fate determination and offer an important tool for establishing pulmonary dysplasia disease in vitro.
problem: Lack of physiologically relevant in vitro models to study respiratory epithelium development and diseases, particularly in understanding lung development and respiratory disorders.
method: Differentiation of fetal mouse proximal epithelial progenitors into 3D airway organoids containing terminal-differentiated ciliated cells and basal stem cells.
innovation: Creation of a 3D organoid system that closely mimics the respiratory epithelium, enabling the study of airway development, epithelial cell fate determination, and modeling of pulmonary diseases in vitro.
application: Used as a model system to investigate lung development, respiratory diseases, and epithelial cell differentiation, particularly for studying pulmonary dysplasia and other airway-related disorders.

1.title: Obtaining Mouse at 13.5 Days of Pregnancy

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Cage one 10–12-week-old adult male mouse and two sexually attracted female mice together at about 6 p.m.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Check female vaginal plugs the next morning; mark the morning of the day when you detect a vaginal plug as E0.5.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3: Weigh mice every day. Pregnant females generally show a detectable increase in body weight from E6.5 onward, with a 0.5–2g increase at E13.5 based on the number of embryos in the womb.

2.title: Separation of the Proximal Airways from E13.5 Embryos

hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Disinfect the stereomicroscope and operating table with 75% ethanol and sterilize the forceps and scissors by autoclaving to minimize the possibility of contamination during the experiment.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Prepare an ice box, 35 and 60mm Petri dishes, and 1.5 and 50~mL tubes containing buffer solution.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Prepare surgical tools: surgical scissors, surgical forceps, and surgical bed, and select an E13.5 pregnant mouse from the laboratory animal house.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Intraperitoneally inject 0.3~mL of chloral hydrate and wait for 5~min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Fix the pregnant mouse to the surgical bed using 4.5-gauge syringe needles.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Disinfect the abdomen area with 75% ethanol.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.4: Pinch and lift the skin with forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.5: Dissect along the mid-abdominal line with surgical scissors, starting from the pubic area and continuing to the end of the abdominal cavity.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Place the uterus with embryos with forceps on the 60mm dish filled with buffer solution maintained on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Separate each embryo from the uterus with the intact yolk sac using forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.3: Remove each embryo from the uterus and keep them in the dish with buffer solution on ice using forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.1: Place one embryo in a 35mm culture dish containing 1~mL of buffer solution using forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2: Discard the yolk sac, amniotic membrane, and umbilical cord under the stereomicroscope using forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.3: Remove the head and abdomen of the embryo, cut the rest under the liver, pull the chest skin of the embryo open, and open the rib-enclosed part of the chest cavity.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.4: Find the red heart part of the embryo mouse and identify the trachea and lung parts around the heart; then, remove the esophagus from the lung and carefully remove the remaining excess tissues with surgical forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.5: Remove the proximal airway with forceps and place in the 35mm culture dish containing buffer solution at 4^°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Under the microscope, using fine-tipped forceps, clean off the connective tissue around the trachea in a 35 mm culture dish.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Open the trachea longitudinally using scissors and further dissect the connected tissue using forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Put all cleaned tracheae into a 1.5mL centrifuge tube containing 1~mL of Pronase solution using forceps, and digest at 4^°C overnight.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Transfer the undigested trachea to a new 1.5mL tube using forceps and use 200uL of mTEC/basic medium to pipette up and down.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.1: Mix the cleaned solution with the mixture of cellular digestive solution. Centrifuge at 800×g for 5min at 37 ^°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.2: Discard the supernatant and add 1 mL of suspension medium.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.3: Use a 300-mesh cell strainer to filter the cell suspension into a new 15~mL tube and centrifuge at 1,000×g for 3min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.1: Resuspend the cells in 1~mL of prewarmed mTEC/basic medium and transfer into a 1.5mL tube.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.2: Prepare type I rat tail collagen coated 35mm dish.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.3: Place the cell suspension prepared in step C9 on a 35mm dish coated type I rat tail collagen. Incubate at 5% CO_2 at 37 ^°C for ^3~h~.

4.title: 3D In Vitro Culture of Proximal Epithelial Progenitors

hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Thaw Matrigel on ice overnight at 4^°C before use.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Add 100~uL of Matrigel in the bottom of a 24-well plate and place it at 37 ^°C for 30min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.1: Centrifuge the proximal airway progenitor cells at 1,000×g for 10min at 37^°C and discard the supernatant.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.2: Resuspend the cells in mTEC/Plus2 medium.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.3: Cell counting: We use a cell counter to calculate the number of cells, and we control 800 cells per 100~uL of cell suspension.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.1: Mix Matrigel with the cell suspension on ice at a ratio of 1:1.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.2: Inoculate a ratio of 800 cells per well on the center of the Matrigel-coated 24-well plate and ensure cell growth in the 3D droplet shape of Matrigel.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.3: Incubate at 5% CO_2 at 37 ^°C for 18 days.

5.title: Identification of Airway Organoids by Immunofluorescence Staining

hierarchical_protocol.5.1.3: Add 1~mL of pre-cooled PBS to each well.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.4: Coat the 15mL tube and pipette tip using 1% BSA solution to wash the tube wall.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Centrifuge at 70×g for 3 min at 4^°C before soaking the fixed organoids overnight in PBS with 10% sucrose at 4^°C.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Use a cutting pipette tip to place the organoids on the sample table and add OCT; then, directly freeze in a pre-cooled -20~^°C frozen cryostat.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.1: Thaw frozen sections in a sealed environment to avoid damage by frozen water crystals.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.2: Incubate with 0.5% Triton X-100 in PBS for 15min.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.3: Block with blocking buffer for 30min at RT.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.4: Dilute the antibody with dilution buffer in different proportions and mix well in 1.5mL centrifuge tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.5: Add to the tissue drop by drop and cover with parafilm M wrapping film to prevent evaporation.

title: Mouse Model of Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-Induced Pulpitis
abstract: Pulpitis is an important and prevalent disease within the oral cavity. Thus, animal models are necessary tools for basic research focused on pulpitis. Researchers worldwide often use dogs and miniature pigs to construct animal models of pulpitis. However, gene editing in miniature pigs is difficult, the surgical modeling process is complex, and tooth demineralization time is lengthy. Although some researchers have attempted to establish a mouse model of pulpitis, most models have involved direct exposure of dental pulp. However, the causes of pulpitis vary considerably among individuals, hindering effective research. In this study, we established a mouse model of pulpitis by accessing the pulp cavity, exposing the pulp to lipopolysaccharide (LPS), and then filling the tooth. One day after surgery, we observed many necrotic tissues and extensive inflammatory exudate, including neutrophils, around the coronal cavity preparation. Additionally, we noted many more neutrophils and a small amount of chronic inflammatory cell infiltrates at the junction between inflamed and normal tissue. These findings indicated that our model can be used to explore the early stage of pulpitis. Ten days after surgery, we observed vacuolar degeneration in some fibroblasts and proliferation in others at the distal end of the inflamed tissue. We also noted dilation and congestion of the pulp blood vessels. Therefore, our model can also be used to explore the middle and later stages of pulpitis. Thirty days after surgery, we observed necrosis in the coronal pulp cavity and upper half of the root pulp, indicating that our model can also be used to explore the end stage of pulpitis. This model is easy to establish, shows pulpitis progression in the dental pulp, exhibits a clear inflammatory phenotype, and can be readily combined with gene editing techniques. Accordingly, it is suitable for basic research focused on pulpitis and has substantial practical value.
problem: The complexity and variability of pulpitis models in animals hinder effective research. Current models using dogs and miniature pigs are surgically complex, time-consuming, and difficult for gene editing, while existing mouse models often involve direct pulp exposure, which does not reflect diverse causes of pulpitis.
method: A mouse model of pulpitis was established by accessing the pulp cavity, exposing pulp to lipopolysaccharide (LPS), and filling the tooth. Histopathological observations were conducted at 1, 10, and 30 days post-surgery to assess inflammation and tissue changes.
innovation: Simplified modeling process, clear progression of pulp inflammation stages (early, middle, late, and end stage), compatibility with gene editing techniques, and a phenotype that mimics clinical pulpitis progression.
application: Suitable for basic research on pulpitis, particularly for studying inflammation mechanisms, tissue degeneration, regeneration, and testing therapeutic interventions. It is adaptable to genetic studies due to ease of gene editing in mice.

# Biological materials

1.  C57BL/6JCnc (B6J) mice (Beijing Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co., Ltd., Beijing) Eight-week-old C57BL/6 mice, weighing 25-30g , were purchased from Beijing Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co., Ltd. and maintained in a pathogen-free environment within Capital Medical University Animal Experiment Center. All animal experiments were approved by the ethics committee of Capital Medical University (AEEI-2024-071). Mice were maintained on a 12:12 h light/dark cycle and given food and water ad libitum. C57BL/6 mice, among the most popular inbred mouse strains in many research laboratories worldwide, were used in the experiments described below.

# Solutions

# Recipes

1. 1.2% tribromoethanol

()
Weigh 0.12g of tribromoethanol using an electronic scale with 0.001 g accuracy and dissolve it in 10mL of distilled water; then, mix thoroughly with a vortex mixer.

2.  0.9% NaCl

()
Weigh 0.9 g of NaCl using an electronic scale with 0.1 g accuracy and dissolve it completely in 100~mL of distilled water.

3.  1 mg/mL LPS-Pg

()

a.  Aspirate 1 mL of endotoxin-free water with a 1~mL injection syringe and inject it into a glass medicine bottle containing 1~mg of LPS-Pg powder; mix these components to obtain a 1 mg/mL LPS- nablaPg solution. b.  Aliquot and label the LPS- nablaPg solution in sterile 0.1~mL tubes and freeze them at -20~^°C until use. Note: L P S-P g solution at a concentration of 100 mg/mL is stable for > months if stored at -20^°C. .

4. 95% ethyl alcohol

()

Using a 100~mL graduated cylinder, measure 95~mL of absolute ethanol and transfer it to a 100~mL beaker.
Using a 5mL graduated cylinder, measure 5mL of distilled water and add it to the beaker containing ethanol.
Add a magnetic stir bar to the beaker, place the beaker on a magnetic stirrer, and stir for 5min . Cite as: Shao, L. et al. (2024). Mouse Model of Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-Induced Pulpitis. Bio-protocol 14(23): e5128.
DOI: 10.21769/BioProtoc.5128.

5. 90% ethyl alcohol

()

Add a magnetic stir bar to the beaker, place the beaker on a magnetic stirrer, and stir for 5min .

6. 85% ethyl alcohol

()
Using a 100~mL graduated cylinder, measure 85~mL of absolute ethanol and transfer it to a 100~mL beaker. Using a 25mL graduated cylinder, measure 15mL of distilled water and add it to the beaker containing ethanol. Add a magnetic stir bar to the beaker, place the beaker on a magnetic stirrer, and stir for 5min .

7. 1% hydrochloric acid alcohol solution

()
Using a 100~mL graduated cylinder, measure 99~mL of absolute ethanol and transfer it to a 100~mL beaker. Using a 1,000~uL pipette, measure 1,000~uL of hydrochloric acid and add it to the beaker containing ethanol. Add a magnetic stir bar to the beaker, place the beaker on a magnetic stirrer, and stir for 30~s .

# 8. 0.2% glacial acetic acid

()
Using a 200~uL pipette, measure 200~uL of glacial acetic acid and add it to a 100~mL volumetric flask. Add distilled water to the flask while stirring with a glass rod until the solution reaches a volume of 100mL .

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Prepare Recipes 1–8 following the instructions provided in Recipes section.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Autoclaving of the modeling instruments: Within 1–5 days before modeling, place the modeling instruments in a stainless-steel lunch box and sterilize them using an autoclave.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Weigh the C57BL/6 mouse using a beaker and an electronic scale with 0.1~g~ accuracy.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Use 1.2% tribromoethanol (see Recipes) for anesthesia (intraperitoneal injection), with a dosage of 0.5mL per 20g body weight.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Pinch the mouse’s toe to check its reaction.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Secure the mouse to the surgical pad with medical adhesive tape; this will ensure that the mouse cannot interrupt the surgery.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Open the mouse’s oral cavity with curved ophthalmic forceps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Use dressing forceps to expand the oral cavity and protect the tongue, thus preventing injury by the diamond bur; concurrently, completely expose the upper portion of the mouth.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Use the diamond bur to access the maxillary first molar in the mouse, then expand the pulp exposure with the dental file; the final diameter of exposure should be approximately 1mm.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Aspirate 0.1~mL of 0.9% NaCl solution (see Recipes) with a 1~mL injection syringe.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Place the tip of the needle over the medullary foramen and quickly empty the syringe to flush out any dentin debris that may have entered the medullary foramen.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.1: Extract 10~uL of 1~mg/mL LPS- Pg (see Recipes) into a 0.1~mL centrifuge tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2: Use straight ophthalmic forceps to completely saturate a small cotton ball in the LPS- nablaPg solution.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.3: Keep the saturated small cotton ball on the exposed pulp for 5:min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.6.1: Remove the cotton ball and restore the tooth with Esthet-X flow.
hierarchical_protocol.2.6.2: After surgery, loosen the mouse’s restraints; return the mouse to the cage after it has awakened.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Sacrifice the mouse by cervical dislocation; carefully harvest maxillary tissue with straight ophthalmic forceps tweezers and ophthalmic scissors.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Place the maxillary tissues into a 15~mL centrifuge tube with 10% paraformaldehyde fixative (neutral) and incubate at room temperature for 24h.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Place printed labels and tissues in sequential order in an embedding frame.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Then, place them in a basin, fill it with fresh decalcification solution, seal the container, and store all components in a constant temperature shaker at 25~^°C with a speed of 110 RPM.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Remove the softened tissue from the decalcification solution, rinse with tap water for ^5~h~, place it into a dehydrating basket, and dehydrate using an alcohol gradient in the dehydrator.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Prepare reagents for dehydration and wax infiltration: alcohol (75%, 85%, 90%, 95%), anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III), benzyl alcohol, xylene (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), and melted paraffin (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III).
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.1: Transfer the wax-infiltrated tissue to the embedding machine.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.2: First, place the melted wax into the embedding frame. Then, place the tissue into the embedding frame according to the requirements of the embedding surface, and attach appropriate labels before the wax solidifies.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Use the trimmed wax block to prepare 4um thick paraffin sections.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Float sections in warm water at 40^°C to flatten the tissue.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Collect the sections and bake them in an oven at 60^°C.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Prepare reagents: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), and 75% ethyl alcohol.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Immerse paraffin sections in the following sequence: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution I for 20 min, environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution II for 20min, anhydrous ethanol I for 5min, anhydrous ethanol II for 5min, and 75% ethyl alcohol for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Stain the sections with hematoxylin solution for 3-5 min and rinse with tap water.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Next, immerse the sections in hematoxylin differentiation solution and rinse with tap water.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.3: Finally, immerse the sections in hematoxylin bluing solution and rinse with tap water.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.1: Immerse sections in the following sequence of solutions: 85% ethanol for 5~min, 95% ethanol for 5~min, and eosin dye for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.5.4.1: Prepare reagents for dehydration and wax infiltration: absolute ethanol (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III) and xylene (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II).
hierarchical_protocol.5.4.2: Immerse sections in the following sequence of solutions: absolute ethanol I for 5min, absolute ethanol II for 5:min, absolute ethanol III for 5:min, xylene Ⅰ for 5:min, and xylene Ⅱ for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1.1: Prepare reagents: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III) and anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III).
hierarchical_protocol.6.1.2: Sequentially immerse the sections in the following sequence: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution I for 10 min, environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution II for 10 min, environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution III for 10 min, absolute ethanol I for 5 min, absolute ethanol II for 5min, and absolute ethanol III for 5~min.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.1: Place the sections in a water bath for 30min.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.2: After retrieval is complete, allow sections to cool naturally.
hierarchical_protocol.6.3.1: Dry the sections and use a hydrophobic pen to draw a circle around the tissue.
hierarchical_protocol.6.3.2: Apply 3% BSA for 30min to block nonspecific binding.
hierarchical_protocol.6.4.1: Prepare primary antibody: dilute the primary antibodies (DSPP 1:100; MPO 1:500) in PBS buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.6.4.2: Add the diluted primary antibody to the sections, ensuring that they are lying flat in a humidified chamber.
hierarchical_protocol.6.5.1: Wash the sections three times in PBS itOmega(pH7.4) ) on a decolorization shaker for 5~min per wash.
hierarchical_protocol.6.5.2: Add the secondary antibody (Cy3-labeled goat anti-mouse IgG) and incubate for 50~min at room temperature in the dark.
hierarchical_protocol.6.6.1: Wash the sections three times in PBS (pH7.4) ) on a decolorization shaker for 5~min per wash.
hierarchical_protocol.6.6.2: Add the DAPI staining reagent and incubate for 10min at room temperature in the dark.
hierarchical_protocol.6.7.1: Wash the sections three times in PBS (pH7.4) on a decolorization shaker for 5 min per wash.
hierarchical_protocol.6.7.2: Add tissue autofluorescence quenching agent B and incubate for 10min at room temperature in the dark.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.1: Prepare reagents: Xylene (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), and 75% ethyl alcohol.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.2: Sequentially immerse the paraffin sections in the following sequence: xylene I for 20 min, xylene II for 20 min, anhydrous ethanol I for 5min, anhydrous ethanol II for 5min, and 75% ethyl alcohol for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.1: Mix Goldner staining solution A and Goldner staining solution B in equal proportions.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.2: Place sections in the mixed solution and stain for 20min.

7.3.title: Staining with Goldner Staining Solution C

hierarchical_protocol.7.3.1: Immerse sections in the first jar of Goldner staining solution C for 10min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.2: Quickly rinse with 0.2% glacial acetic acid (3 s per rinse).

7.4.title: Staining with Goldner Staining Solution D

hierarchical_protocol.7.4.1: Immerse sections in Goldner staining solution D for 3 min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.4.2: Monitor the staining under a microscope; ensure that Goldner staining solution C fades from the collagen areas.

7.5.title: Staining with Goldner Staining Solution C

hierarchical_protocol.7.5.1: Immerse sections in the second jar of Goldner staining solution C for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.5.2: Quickly rinse with 0.2% glacial acetic acid (3 s per rinse).

7.6.title: Staining with Goldner Staining Solution E

hierarchical_protocol.7.6.1: Immerse sections in Goldner staining solution E for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.6.2: Then, differentiate the stain using three jars of 0.2% glacial acetic acid (2 s per jar).
hierarchical_protocol.7.7.1: Place sections in the third jar of anhydrous ethanol for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.7.2: Clear the sections in xylene for 5 min.

8.title: Perform Microscopy Examination, Image Acquisition, and Analysis

hierarchical_protocol.8.1: HE staining: Nuclei will be stained blue, whereas cytoplasm will be stained red.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2: Immunofluorescence staining: DAPI (excitation wavelength 330-380 nm, emission wavelength 420nm ) will stain nuclei blue, whereas Cy3 (excitation wavelength 510-560nm, mission wavelength 590nm ) will stain the target protein red.
hierarchical_protocol.8.3: Goldner trichrome staining: mineralized bone will be stained green, whereas non-mineralized tissue will be stained orange red.

title: A Microplate-Based Expression Monitoring System for Arabidopsis NITRATE TRANSPORTER2.1 Using the Luciferase Reporter
abstract: Gene expression analysis is a fundamental technique to elucidate the regulatory mechanisms of genes of interest or to reveal the patterns of plant response to environmental stimuli. Traditionally, gene expression analyses have required RNA extraction, followed by cDNA synthesis and qPCR analyses. However, this conventional method is costly and time-consuming, limiting the amount of data collected. The protocol outlined in this study, which utilizes a chemiluminescence system, offers a cost-effective and rapid method for assessing the expression of Arabidopsis (Arabidopsis thaliana) genes, exemplified by analyzing the nitrate-inducible expression of a major nitrate transporter gene, nitrate transporter 2.1 (NRT2.1). A reporter construct, containing the NRT2.1 promoter fused to the firefly luciferase gene, was introduced into wild-type and mutant Arabidopsis plants. Seeds obtained from the transgenic lines were grown for 3 days in 96-well microplates containing a nitrate-free nutrient solution. After 3 days, the nutrient solution was replaced with a fresh batch, which was supplemented with luciferin potassium. One hour later, nitrate was added at various concentrations, and the temporal expression pattern of NRT2.1 was analyzed by monitoring the chemiluminescence signals. This method allowed for the cost-effective, quantitative, and highthroughput analysis of NRT2.1 expression over time under the effects of various nutrient conditions and genetic backgrounds.
problem: Traditional gene expression analysis using RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and qPCR is costly, time-consuming, and limits data collection, hindering high-throughput studies.
method: A microplate-based chemiluminescence system using a reporter construct (NRT2.1 promoter fused to firefly luciferase gene) to monitor gene expression in Arabidopsis plants under nitrate conditions.
innovation: Cost-effective and rapid method, high-throughput capability, quantitative and temporal expression analysis, eliminates the need for RNA extraction and qPCR, and enables monitoring of gene expression in response to varying nutrient conditions and genetic backgrounds.
application: Ideal for studying Arabidopsis gene expression, particularly nitrate-inducible genes like NRT2.1, adaptable to other genes and plant species, useful for high-throughput screening of environmental and genetic effects on gene regulation.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Place transgenic Arabidopsis seeds in a 1.5mL tube.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Mix 860µL of sterile deionized water and 140µL of 5% sodium hypochlorite in a 1.5mL tube.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Vigorously mix the contents of the tube using a vortex mixer.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Centrifugate briefly (5s) at 2,000×g and remove the supernatant with a pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.4.1: Rinse the seeds with 1mL of sterile deionized water, vortex, and remove the supernatant after a brief centrifugation (5s at 2,000×g).
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Place the seeds in a refrigerator (4°C) along with a small amount of water, enough to cover the seeds, for 2-3 days.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Add 200µL of nutrient solution (0.1×N-free MS medium + 500µM ammonium succinate) to each well of a 96-well microplate.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Fill the gap between wells with sterile deionized water to prevent evaporation of the nutrient solution.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3: Place four seeds in each well using a pipette tip.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4: Cover the microplate with a transparent lid and seal the lid with surgical tape.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.1: Incubate the plate under continuous light (60µE; around 30cm from the light source) in a growth chamber maintained at 23°C for 3 days.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2.1: Remove the nutrient solution from the wells 15h before measurement of LUC activity.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2.2: Wash the seedlings with 200µL of 0.1×N- and P-free MS medium (+500µM ammonium succinate) once.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2.3: Add 200µL of fresh 0.1×N-free MS medium (+500µM ammonium succinate) containing a reduced amount of phosphorus (0 or 5µM compared with 125µM in the control solution).
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Uncover the plate 1h before treatment onset and remove the solution using an 8-channel pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Add a new nutrient solution (200µL) containing 100µM of luciferin potassium to each well using a single-channel or an 8-channel pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3: Cover the plate with a lid and incubate under light for 1h in the same growth chamber set at 23°C with continuous illumination.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.1: Add potassium nitrate at a final concentration of 0-10mM to each well and mix the contents of each well by pipetting with an 8-channel pipette (at least 5 times).
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Immediately after adding potassium nitrate, transfer the plate to the microplate reader.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Shake the plate for 2s with the linear and 3mm settings of the instrument.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Read the chemiluminescence of each well for 1.5s.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.1: After recording the signal from all wells, transfer the plate back to the incubator set at 23°C with continuous illumination.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.1: Perform steps D2 and D3 at regular intervals (e.g., at 20-min intervals for a total of 360min).

title: In-Gel Activity Assay of Mammalian Mitochondrial and Cytosolic Aconitases, Surrogate Markers of Compartment-Specific Oxidative Stress and Iron Status
abstract: Two aconitase isoforms are present in mammalian cells: the mitochondrial aconitase (ACO2) that catalyzes the reversible isomerization of citrate to isocitrate in the citric acid cycle, and the bifunctional cytosolic enzyme (ACO1), which also plays a role as an RNA-binding protein in the regulation of intracellular iron metabolism. Aconitase activities in the different subcellular compartments can be selectively inactivated by different genetic defects, iron depletion, and oxidative or nitrative stress. Aconitase contains a 4Fe-4S^2+ cluster that is essential for substrate coordination and catalysis. Many Fe-S clusters are sensitive to oxidative stress, nitrative stress, and reduced iron availability, which forms the basis of redox- and iron-mediated regulation of intermediary metabolism via aconitase and other Fe-S cluster-containing metabolic enzymes, such as succinate dehydrogenase. As such, ACO1 and ACO2 activities can serve as compartment-specific surrogate markers of oxygen levels, reactive oxygen species (ROS), reactive nitrogen species (RNS), iron bioavailability, and the status of intermediary and iron metabolism. Here, we provide a protocol describing a non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE)-based procedure that has been successfully used to monitor ACO1 and ACO2 aconitase activities simultaneously in human and mouse cells and tissues.
problem: Accurate detection and differentiation of mitochondrial (ACO2) and cytosolic (ACO1) aconitase activities, which are sensitive to oxidative and nitrative stress, iron depletion, and genetic defects.
method: Non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) to simultaneously monitor ACO1 and ACO2 activities, enabling detection of compartment-specific inactivation.
innovation: Simultaneous in-gel detection of both aconitase isoforms, providing a compartment-specific assessment of oxidative stress, iron status, and metabolic regulation without protein denaturation.
application: Applicable to human and mouse cells and tissues, used as surrogate markers for oxygen levels, ROS, RNS, iron bioavailability, and intermediary metabolism status.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Harvest cell cultures and wash cell pellets 3× with PBS at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Lyse the cell pellets for analysis immediately or flash-freeze cell pellets on dry ice.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.3: Store cell pellets at -80°C until use.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Lyse cell pellets using Triton-citrate or RIPA-citrate extraction buffer at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Add 1-2 v/v of Triton-citrate or RIPA-citrate extraction buffer to each cell pellet.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Disperse cells using a pipette and incubate on ice for 10min with intermittent agitation.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.4: Centrifuge at >16,000×g for 5 min in a refrigerated microcentrifuge and collect the supernatant (protein extract).
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Proceed with protein quantification using Bradford Protein Assay from Bio-Rad.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Follow the manufacturer's protocol for protein quantification.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Harvest tissues, cut into small pieces, and flash-freeze on dry ice.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Chill microcentrifuge tubes containing 100µL of homogenization beads on dry ice.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Weight out 20-40mg of tissue pieces in the microcentrifuge tubes containing the homogenization beads.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: Add 5µL of cold RIPA-citrate extract buffer per milligram of tissue to each tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4: Run the Bullet Blender for 2min at speed 8 at 4°C, wait for 2min, and repeat once.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Centrifuge at 2,000×g for 2min in a refrigerated microcentrifuge and transfer the supernatant into chilled microcentrifuge tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Centrifuge at maximum speed (21,000×g) for 10min at 4°C and transfer the supernatant (tissue RIPA extract) to chilled microcentrifuge tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Use immediately or store at -80°C until use.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Proceed with protein quantification using Bradford Protein Assay from Bio-Rad.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Follow the manufacturer's protocol for protein quantification.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Prepare 1× running buffer and keep it cold (0-4°C).
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Cast the separating gel and overlay with 0.5mL of isopropyl alcohol.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.3: Allow polymerization to occur for 15min at RT and then rinse out the alcohol.

3.2.title: Cast Stacking Gel and Assemble Electrophoresis Cell

hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Cast the stacking gel and insert the well-forming comb without trapping air under the teeth.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Assemble the electrophoresis cell and fill the inner and outer buffer chambers with cold running buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Mix the protein extract with the appropriate amount of loading buffer and deionized H2O.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Load samples slowly to allow them to settle evenly on the bottom of the wells.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.3: Run electrophoresis at constant 170V at 4°C for 2.5-4h for a mini-gel.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Prewarm the H2O for the aconitase activity assay mix.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Add all the assay reagents, except IDH, to the prewarmed H2O.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Remove the gel carefully from between the glass plates and place the gel in a clean tray.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Add IDH to the aconitase activity assay mix and add to the tray containing the gel.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.3: Incubate with gentle agitation at RT or in a 37°C incubator for 5–60min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.1: Wash the gel 5–10 times with H2O, with gentle agitation and protection from direct light.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.2: Dry the gel between a filter paper and a plastic wrap using a gel vacuum dryer or air-drying methods.

title: Shipment of Cyanobacteria by Agarose Gel Embedding (SCAGE)—A Novel Method for Simple and Robust Delivery of Cyanobacteria
abstract: In modern science, the exchange of scientific material between different institutions and collaborating working groups constitutes an indispensable endeavor. For this purpose, bacterial strains are frequently shipped to collaborators to advance joint research projects. Bacterial strains are usually safely shipped as cultures on solid medium, whereas the shipment of liquid cultures requires specific safety measures due to the risk of leakage. Cyanobacterial cultures are frequently maintained as liquid stock cultures, and this problem typically arises. This protocol describes a new method for the shipment of liquid cyanobacterial stock cultures by agarose gel embedding (SCAGE). More specifically, a cyanobacterial culture is mixed with low-melting agarose and cast into sterile plastic bags, resulting in a thin, solid cyanobacterial agarose gel (cyanogel) that can be easily shipped. After delivery, subsequent regeneration of the cyanogel material in liquid media results in full recovery of the examined bacterial strains. Thus, the packaging method devised in the present study comprises an innovative technique to facilitate the shipment of bacterial strains, whilst eliminating previously encountered issues like cell culture leakage.
problem: Challenges in shipping cyanobacterial liquid cultures due to the risk of leakage and the need for specific safety measures, complicating the exchange of bacterial strains between institutions.
method: Cyanobacterial liquid cultures are mixed with low-melting agarose and cast into sterile plastic bags to form a thin, solid cyanobacterial agarose gel (cyanogel) for shipping. Post-delivery, the cyanogel is regenerated in liquid media to recover the bacterial strains.
innovation: Eliminates the risk of leakage during shipment, simplifies the shipping process for liquid cyanobacterial cultures, and ensures full recovery of bacterial strains after delivery. The use of low-melting agarose makes the method robust and easy to handle.
application: Facilitates the safe and efficient transport of cyanobacterial liquid cultures between collaborating institutions, supporting joint research projects. Applicable to various cyanobacterial strains maintained as liquid stock cultures.
input:
Biological materials

1. Synechocystis sp. PCC6803, glucose-tolerant (GT) 9
2. Anabaena (Nostoc) sp. PCC7120 10

# Reagents

1. NaNO3 (Sigma-Aldrich, CAS: 7631-99-4)
2. K_2HPO_4 (water-free) (Sigma-Aldrich, CAS: 7758-11-4)
3. MgSO_47H_2O (AppliChem, CAS: 10034-99-8)

# Recipes

# 1.  BG11 medium (modified after Rippka et al. 11):

a.  Prepare 200~mL of each stock solution (1–7) from Table 1, 100~mL of trace element solution (Table 2), and 50mL of 1 M NaHCO3 solution (Table 3). Use Milli-Q water for each solution.
b.  Stock solutions 1–7 and the trace element solution are sterilized by autoclaving ( 121 ^°C , 15 psi, 20min ), while the 1MNaHCO_3 solution is sterilized by filter sterilization (0.22um) . Note: Store solutions ^l- at room temperature and solution 7 Fe(III)-citrate & citric acid protected from light at room temperature. Store trace solution at 4~^°C and 1 M NaHCO3 at -20^°C.
c. To prepare 1~L~ of BG11 (1×) , add 5~mL of each stock solution 1–7 (200×) , 1~mL of the trace element solution (1,000×) , and up to 995~mL of Milli-Q water. Sterilize by autoclaving ( 121 ^°C , 15 psi, 20min ).

Add 5mL of 1 MNaHCO_3 solution before use. Note: For the modified BG11 medium, conduct the following adjustments: • N a_2C O_3 : 0.04g/L (originally 0.02g/L) . Ferric ammonium citrate was replaced by Fe(III)-citrate.

2. 5% (w/v) agarose low melting (ALM) solution To prepare 100~mL of 5% (w/v) ALM solution, add 5g of ALM in 100~mL of BG11 medium. Sterilize by autoclaving ( 121 ^°C. , 15 psi, 20min ). Store at room temperature.

13. Sterile indicator strip (Roth, catalog number: XC20.1)

# Equipment

2. Pipetboy (VWR, catalog number: 613-4438)
3. Rotary shaker (GFL, catalog number: GFL-3017)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Prepare Erlenmeyer flasks by putting a Steristopper on top and covering with grease-proof paper secured by a rubber band.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Sterilize the prepared Erlenmeyer flask by autoclaving at 121°C, 15 psi, for 20 minutes, and let it cool to room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3: Inoculate Synechocystis sp. PCC6803 GT or Anabaena (Nostoc) sp. PCC7120 in 50mL of BG11 medium under sterile conditions.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4: Grow the cyanobacteria under continuous light illumination at 40umolm^-2s^-1, 120rpm, and 28°C until the stationary phase (OD_750>4) is reached.

2.title: Preparation for Gel Embedding of Cyanobacteria

hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Sterilize disposable bags by autoclaving at 121°C, 15 psi, for 20 minutes, and let them cool down to room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Collect 15mL of liquid bacterial culture, harvest cells by centrifugation at 4000×g for 10 minutes, and resuspend cells in 2mL of BG11 medium.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Heat the 5% (w/v) ALM suspension until a clear, homogenous solution is obtained.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Let the solution cool down to approximately 30°C under the sterile hood.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3: Add 3mL of the 5% (w/v) ALM solution to the resuspended cyanobacterial strain and mix through careful pipetting to form the cyanogel.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4: Transfer the cyanogel into a disposable bag under sterile conditions.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5: Distribute the cyanogel evenly within the bag and apply a slight amount of pressure to obtain a smooth plane.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Place the bag between the contacts of a foil welding machine and close the machine for 3 seconds.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Open the apparatus, wait for 5 seconds, and then label the bag for later identification.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1: Package the embedded cyanobacteria in an appropriate container, such as an envelope, and send it to the desired location.

6.title: Recovering of Cyanobacteria out of the Cyanogel

hierarchical_protocol.6.1: Prepare 50mL of BG11 medium in an Erlenmeyer flask under sterile conditions.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2: Open the received cyanogel, squeeze the gel out of the disposal bag into the BG11 medium, and let the cyanobacteria grow under dimmed light conditions.
hierarchical_protocol.6.3: After 24 hours of incubation, remove the paper towel and cultivate the cyanobacteria under standard cultivation conditions.

title: Quantitative Measurement of the Kinase Activity of Wildtype ALPK1 and Disease-Causing ALPK1 Mutants Using Cell-Free Radiometric Phosphorylation Assays
abstract: ALPK1 is an atypical protein kinase that is activated during bacterial infection by ADP-heptose and phosphorylates TIFA to activate a cell signaling pathway. In contrast, specific mutations in ALPK1 allow it to also be activated by endogenous human nucleotide sugars such as UDP-mannose, leading to the phosphorylation of TIFA in the absence of infection. This protocol describes a quantitative, cell-free phosphorylation assay that can directly measure the catalytic activity of wildtype and disease-causing ALPK1 in the presence of different nucleotide sugars. In this method, overexpressed ALPK1 is first immunoprecipitated from the extracts of ALPK1 knockout HEK-Blue cells transfected with plasmids encoding either FLAG-tagged wildtype or mutant ALPK1, and then subjected to a radioactive phosphorylation assay in which the phosphorylation of purified GST-tagged TIFA by ALPK1 is quantified by measuring the incorporation of radioactivity derived from radiolabeled ATP.
problem: Lack of a direct and quantitative method to measure the kinase activity of wildtype ALPK1 and its disease-causing mutants, particularly in the presence of different nucleotide sugars.
method: Immunoprecipitation of overexpressed ALPK1 from ALPK1 knockout HEK-Blue cells, followed by a radioactive phosphorylation assay to quantify TIFA phosphorylation using radiolabeled ATP.
innovation: Enables direct measurement of ALPK1 kinase activity in a cell-free system, allows differentiation between wildtype and mutant ALPK1 activation by nucleotide sugars, and provides quantitative results through radioactive labeling.
application: Useful for studying ALPK1's role in bacterial infection and disease-causing mutations, particularly in understanding its activation by nucleotide sugars and its phosphorylation of TIFA.
input:
Biological materials

Cells should be cultured by incubation at 37^°C with 5%CO_2 and tested regularly for mycoplasma using a MycoAlert Mycoplasma Detection Kit (Lonza, catalog number: LT07-318). The cells should be passaged once confluent at a ratio of 1:10(v/v) , and not used beyond 30 passages.

1.  ALPK1 knockout (KO) HEK-Blue cells (InvivoGen, #hkb-koalpk)

# General reagents

Storage conditions are given in parentheses unless it is room temperature.

1. ADP-L-heptose triethylammonium salt (InvivoGen, catalog number: tlrl-adph-l) (-80^°C) Note: Resuspend 250mu g in 3,470 µL of reaction buffer (see Recipes) to generate a 0.1 mM stock.

# Purified proteins

TIFA was purified from bacteria as a GST fusion and is available upon request via the MRC PPU Reagents and Services website (https://mrcppureagents.dundee.ac.uk). 1.  GST-TIFA2-184 (MRC PPU Reagents and Services, catalog number: DU4241) (-80^°C) Note: Dialyzed against reaction buffer and stored at 1 mg/mL in single-use aliquots.

The yield was 0.5~mg , resuspended to 0.5mg/mL in endotoxin-free water. They are stored at -20~^°C . 1.  pcDNA5-FRT/TO-FLAG-ALPK1 (MRC PPU Reagents and Services, catalog number: DU65668) 2.  pcDNA5-FRT-TO-FLAG-ALPK1S277F (MRC PPU Reagents and Services, catalog number: DU71952) 3.  pcDNA5-FRT-TO-FLAG (MRC PPU Reagents and Services, catalog number: DU41457)

1.  Image Lab (BioRad, Version 6.0.1)

1.title: Preparation of ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue Cells

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Prepare two confluent 15-cm dishes of ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue cells, no higher than passage 30.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Ensure the cells are cultured at 37°C with 5% CO2.

2.title: Transient Expression of FLAG-tagged ALPK1 Constructs

hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Plate 15 million ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue cells into each of 3 × 15-cm dishes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Aspirate the culture media from two confluent 15-cm dishes of cells and replace with 10 mL of PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Aspirate the PBS and add 3 mL of trypsin-EDTA solution to each dish.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: Add 15 mL of culture media to each plate and pipette up and down to produce a single-cell suspension.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4: Count the number of cells using standard methods, ensuring cell viability is at least 90%.

2.3.title: Transfection of ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue Cells

hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Prepare lipofectamine 2000 and OptiMEM for transfection.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Dilute 60 μg of each plasmid in 600 μL of OptiMEM.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Add the diluted lipofectamine 2000 to each diluted plasmid and incubate for 10 minutes at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.4: Add each solution dropwise to the relevant dish of cells and return them to the incubator.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: After 4 hours, carefully aspirate the culture media and add 15 mL of fresh culture media.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Return the plates to the incubator for 20 hours.

3.title: Preparation and Normalization of Cell Extracts

hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Twenty-four hours post-transfection, detach the cells using a serological pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Centrifuge the tubes at 800 × g for 5 minutes at room temperature to pellet the cells.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.3: Wash the cells with PBS and centrifuge again.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.4: Add 1 mL of ice-cold lysis buffer to each cell pellet and pipette up and down until a homogenous suspension is formed.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Determine the protein concentration in each cell extract using the Bradford protein assay kit.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Dilute the cell extracts to a final concentration of 2 mg/mL protein using ice-cold lysis buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.3: Immunoprecipitate each cell extract using anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.4: Analyze the immunoprecipitated samples by SDS-PAGE and quantify the intensity of each FLAG-ALPK1 mutant.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Prepare 0.5 mL aliquots of each cell extract on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Snap-freeze the aliquots and store them at -80°C until use.

4.title: Determination of Linear Rate Conditions for WT ALPK1

hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Thaw two aliquots of WT FLAG-ALPK1 lysate on ice and combine them.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Prepare anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin slurry and wash the resin with ice-cold lysis buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.3: Resuspend the resin in ice-cold reaction buffer and aliquot into individual microcentrifuge tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.4: Add GST-TIFA and radioactive ATP solution to each tube and incubate at 30°C.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Analyze the samples by SDS-PAGE and stain with InstantBlue.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Destain the gel and cut out individual bands corresponding to GST-TIFA.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.3: Count each sample using a scintillation counter and plot the resulting data.

5.title: Measurement of the Activity of ALPK1 Mutants

hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Thaw an aliquot of each cell extract on ice and prepare anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin slurry.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Wash the resin with ice-cold lysis buffer and resuspend in ice-cold reaction buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.3: Add GST-TIFA and radioactive ATP solution to each tube and incubate at 30°C.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.4: Terminate the reactions and analyze the samples by SDS-PAGE.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Analyze the incorporation of radioactivity into GST-TIFA by scintillation counting.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Plot the resulting data and compare the activity of ALPK1 mutants.

title: Compartment-Resolved Proteomics with Deep Extracellular Matrix Coverage
abstract: The extracellular matrix (ECM) is a complex network of proteins that provides structural support and biochemical cues to cells within tissues. Characterizing ECM composition is critical for understanding this tissue component’s roles in development, homeostasis, and disease processes. This protocol describes an integrated pipeline for profiling both cellular and ECM proteins across varied tissue types using mass spectrometry–based proteomics. The workflow covers stepwise extraction of cellular and extracellular proteins, enzymatic digestion into peptides, peptide cleanup, mass spectrometry analysis, and bioinformatic data processing. The key advantages include unbiased coverage of cellular, ECM-associated, and core-ECM proteins, including the fraction of ECM that cannot be solubilized using strong chaotropic agents such as urea or guanidine hydrochloride. Additionally, the method has been optimized for reproducible ECM enrichment and quantification across diverse tissue samples. This protocol enables systematic mapping of the ECM at a proteome-wide scale.
problem: The need for a comprehensive and compartment-resolved method to characterize the complex composition of the extracellular matrix (ECM) and its role in tissues. Existing methods often fail to cover insoluble ECM components and lack reproducibility across tissue types.
method: An integrated pipeline involving stepwise extraction of cellular and extracellular proteins, enzymatic digestion into peptides, peptide cleanup, mass spectrometry analysis, and bioinformatic data processing.
innovation: Unbiased coverage of cellular, ECM-associated, and core-ECM proteins, including insoluble ECM fractions. Optimized for high reproducibility and wide applicability across diverse tissue samples.
application: Proteome-wide mapping of ECM and cellular proteins in various tissue types, facilitating studies in development, homeostasis, and disease processes.
input:
Reagents

1.  Tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane hydrochloride (Tris-HCl) (Roche, catalog number: 10812846001)
2. 3-((3-cholamidopropyl) dimethylammonio)-1-propanesulfonate (CHAPS) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: C3023)
3.  Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: E4884)
4.  Sodium chloride (NaCl) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: S9888)
5. Halt protease inhibitor cocktail (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: 78429)
6. Guanidine hydrochloride (Gnd-HCl) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: G4505)
7.  Hydroxylamine-HCl NH_2OH-HCl) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: 159417)
8.  Ammonium bicarbonate (ABC) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: A6141)
9.  Double-distilled water (ddH_2O)
10. Dithiothreitol (DTT) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: D9779)
11. Iodoacetamide (IAM) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: I1149)
12. Potassium carbonate (K_2CO_3) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: 209619)
13. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: S5881)
14. Urea (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: U5128)
15. Buffer A: 0.1% formic acid (FA) in H_2O , Optima (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: LS118)
16. Buffer B: 0.1% FA in 80% ACN, Optima (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: LS122500)
17. Sequencing-grade modified trypsin (Promega, catalog number: V5111)
18. Lysyl Endopeptidase®, mass spectrometry grade (Lys-C) (FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, catalog number: 125-05061)
19. Optional (if necessary based on protocol notes): a.  Gel-loading pipette tips (Corning, catalog number: CLS4853) b.  OptimaTM acetone (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: A929) c.  Pierce ^TM660nm protein quantification assay (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: 22660)

# Solutions

1. High salt buffer (see Recipes)
2. Gnd-HCl solution (see Recipes)
3. DTT solution (see Recipes)
4. IAM solution (see Recipes)

Cite as: McCabe, M. C. et al. (2024). Compartment-Resolved Proteomics with Deep Extracellular Matrix Coverage. Bioprotocol 14(23): e5123. DOI: 10.21769/BioProtoc.5123.

5. Hydroxylamine (HA) buffer preparation (pH9.0) (see Recipes)
6. Urea solution (see Recipes)
7. Digest master mix (per sample) (see Recipes)

# Recipes

1.  High salt buffer

()
Combine buffer components and bring to 100~mL with ddH2O. Buffer without protease inhibitors can be prepared in advance and stored at 4^°C for up to one month. Protease inhibitors must be added fresh before use.

# 2.  Gnd-HCl solution

()
Dissolve Gnd-HCl in ddH2O before adding 10mL of 1 M ABC. Adjust pH to 9.0 using NaOH. Add ddH2O to 100mL . Prepare fresh before use.

# 3.  DTT solution

()
Combine components and add ddH_2O to 10mL . Prepare fresh before use.

4.  IAM solution

()
Combine components and add ddH_2O to 10mL . Prepare fresh before use and store in the dark.

5.  Hydroxylamine (HA) buffer preparation (f p H9.0)

()

Prepare Gnd-HCl solution according to Recipe 2. Dissolve NH_2OH-HCl in 50mL of Gnd-HCl solution. Add NaOH, mix, then add K_2CO_3 . Add Gnd-HCl solution to 90mL before adjusting pH to 9.0 using HCl. Add GndHCl solution to 100mL . Prepare fresh before use.

6. Urea solution

()
Combine components and add ddH_2O to 50mL . Prepare fresh before use.

# 7.  Digest master mix (per sample)

()

# Laboratory supplies

2. Safe-Lock 1.75mL tubes (Eppendorf, catalog number: 003012361)

4. Glass beads, 1mm diameter (Next Advance, catalog number: GB10)
5. 10kDa molecular weight cutoff (MWCO) filters (Sartorius, catalog number: VN01H02)

# Equipment

2. Measuring pipettes, p1000, p200, p10 (any brand)

C18 resin (Waters). Commercial alternative: EASY-Spray C18 column, 75~um i.d. × 150 mm fused silica
capillary packed with 3 um resin (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: ES900)

# Software and datasets

1. XCalibur Version 4.5 (Thermo Fisher)
2. Mascot Server Version 2.5 (Matrix Science)
3. Proteome Discoverer Version 2.5 (Thermo Fisher)

7. MatrisomeDB 15

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Mill flash-frozen tissue samples in liquid nitrogen using a mortar and pestle until a fine powder is produced.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Lyophilize milled, frozen tissue samples in a clean fast-freeze flask (Labconco) of appropriate size for your sample set, ensuring that vessel pressure remains below 400 uBar during the entire lyophilization process.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Once samples have been completely dried (5-16h depending on tissue type and size), remove samples from the lyophilizer.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: After lyophilization, store milled and dried samples in 1.75 mL safe-lock tubes at -80°C until further processing.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Weigh approximately 5mg (dry weight) of milled, lyophilized tissue into a 1.5mL safe-lock tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Add 100mg of 1mm glass beads to each sample tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.3: Add ice-cold high salt buffer to each sample tube at 200 uL/mg starting dry weight.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Homogenize samples in buffer using the bead beater (Bullet Blender) for 3 min on power 8.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Vortex samples at maximum power for 20min at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: Centrifuge samples at 18,000×g for 20min in a 4°C refrigerated centrifuge.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Remove supernatant, being careful to avoid disturbing the pellet, and reserve as fraction 1.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Repeat steps B3–B7 two additional times, producing fractions 2 and 3.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Combine fractions 1–3 to produce the cellular fraction.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Homogenize ECM-enriched pellets in Gnd-HCl solution at 200uL/mg of the initial tissue dry weight using the Bullet Blender at power 8 for 1 min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Vortex the homogenate at room temperature (25°C) overnight at power 5.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: After vortexing, centrifuge the homogenate at 18,000×g for 20min at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Collect the supernatant and reserve it as the soluble ECM (sECM) fraction.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Treat remaining pellets with freshly prepared HA buffer at 200 uL/mg of the initial tissue dry weight.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Homogenize using the Bullet Blender at power 8 for 1 min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.3: Incubate at 45°C with shaking on an orbital shaker (1,000rpm) for 4h.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Collect supernatant and reserve as the insoluble ECM (iECM) fraction.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Aliquot a volume of each extract, which corresponds to roughly 30ug of protein for each sample, into individual 1.5mL tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Add urea buffer to bring each sample to 250uL.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Add DTT solution to a final concentration of 10mM.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.3: Add IAM solution to a final concentration of 22mM.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.1: Add 100uL of urea solution to each filter and centrifuge filters at 14,000×g for 15min.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.2: Load entire reduced and alkylated samples onto equilibrated 10 kDa MWCO filters.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1.1: Prepare an 8-point standard curve by diluting the peptide standard included with the PierceTM quantitative colorimetric peptide assay into 0.2% FA.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.1: Load 20uL of each standard curve point and each sample into individual wells of a clear, flat-bottom 96-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.2: Add 180uL of working reagent to each sample in the 96-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.1: Load PierceTM C18 spin tips into 2mL tubes using the provided adapters.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.2: Wash resin using 70uL of 0.1% FA in 80% ACN.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.1: Load sample onto C18 spin tips.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.1: Elute peptides with two consecutive washes of 70uL of 0.1% FA in 80% ACN.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.2: Transfer eluted samples to autosampler vials and freeze for 15min at -80°C.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.1: Inject 8uL of each prepared sample at a maximum pressure of 700 bar into a 20uL sample loop on the EASY-nLC 1200 system.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.1: Elute samples from the analytical column at a flow rate of 400nL/min over a 120-min gradient.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.2: Analyze the injected samples using data-dependent acquisition according to the following parameters.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1.1: Analyze data using Mascot integrated with Proteome Discoverer.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1.2: Search the data against the appropriate UniProt database for your organism using the following parameters.
hierarchical_protocol.9.2.1: Filter results to 1% false discovery rate (FDR) at the peptide level using the Percolator node.
hierarchical_protocol.9.2.2: Perform label-free quantification (LFQ) using the Precursor Ions Quantifier node.

title: Development of a Rapid Epstein–Barr Virus Detection System Based on Recombinase Polymerase Amplification and a Lateral Flow Assay
abstract: The quality of cellular products used in biological research can impact the accuracy of results. Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) is a latent virus that spreads extensively worldwide, and cell lines used in experiments may carry EBV and pose an infection risk. The presence of EBV in a single cell line can contaminate other cell lines used in the same laboratory, affecting experimental results. Existing tests to detect EBV can be divided into three categories: nucleic acid assays, serological assays, and in situ hybridization assays. However, most methods are time-consuming, expensive, and not conducive to high-volume clinical screening. Therefore, a simple system that allows for the rapid detection of EBV in multiple contexts, including both cell culture and tissue samples, remains necessary. In our research, we developed EBV detection systems: (1) a polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based detection system, (2) a recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA)-based detection system, and (3) a combined RPA-lateral flow assay (LFA) detection system. The minimum EBV detection limits were 1×10^3 copy numbers for the RPA-based and RPA-LFA systems and 1×10^4 copy numbers for the PCR-based system. Both the PCR and RPA detection systems were applied to 192 cell lines, and the results were consistent with those of the assays specified in industry standards. A total of 10 EBV-positive cell lines were identified. The combined RPA-LFA system is simple to operate, allowing for rapid result visualization. This system can be implemented in laboratories and cell banks as part of a daily quality control strategy to ensure cell quality and experimental safety and may represent a potential new technique for the rapid detection of EBV in clinical samples.
problem: Need for a rapid, cost-effective, and high-throughput method to detect Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) in cell lines and tissue samples. Existing methods are time-consuming, expensive, and not suitable for large-scale screening, posing risks of contamination and experimental inaccuracy.
method: Development of three detection systems: (1) PCR-based, (2) RPA-based, and (3) a combined RPA-lateral flow assay (RPA-LFA) system. The systems were tested for sensitivity and applied to 192 cell lines to validate their accuracy compared to industry-standard assays.
innovation: The RPA-LFA system offers rapid, simple, and cost-effective detection with a sensitivity of 1×10^3 EBV copy numbers, faster visualization of results, and ease of operation. It outperforms the PCR-based system in sensitivity and accessibility.
application: Suitable for EBV detection in cell lines, tissue samples, and clinical settings. Ideal for laboratories and cell banks as part of a daily quality control strategy to ensure cell quality and experimental safety. Potential for clinical diagnostics.

# Biological materials

1. B95-8 cell line (China Center for Type Culture Collection, GDC0015)
2. HeLa cell line (China Center for Type Culture Collection, GDC0009)
3. Epstein–Barr virus (China Center for Type Culture Collection, GDV132)

# Reagents

1. Trypsin (AMEKO, catalog number: RC01145)
2. Ethanol (National Pharmaceutical Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., catalog number: 10009228)
3. PBS (Gibco, catalog number: 70013032)

5. E.Z.N.A Viral DNA Kit (OMEGA, catalog number: D3892)

7. DL2,000 DNA marker (Takara, catalog number: 3427A)
