1.title: Primer & Probe & Lateral Flow Strip Design

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Download the nucleic acid sequence of EBV from NCBI (Genebank: V01555).
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Design PCR and RPA primers for conserved regions using DNAMAN 8.0 software.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.3: Design primers that can participate in both PCR and RPA.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Select the same amplified fragments as in PCR but with BIOTIN modification at the 5' end of the reverse primer.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Introduce a probe to enhance amplification specificity.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Design the probe with a FITC modification at the 5' end, a modifying group (C3-Spacer) at the 3' end, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) labeled in the middle.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Immobilize gold particles of BIOTIN antibody and FITC antibody on a lateral flow strip (test line).
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: The target fragment will be captured to appear as a positive band.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Collect cells in good growth condition, centrifuge with trypsin digestion, and aspirate the cell suspension.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Use the blood/cell/tissue genomic DNA extraction kit of Tiangen Biochemical Technology (Beijing) Co.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.3: Add 1mL of PBS reagent to keep the cells in suspension, resuspend to rewash the cell precipitate, and centrifuge at 9,306×g for 1min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.4: Add 200~uL of buffer solution GA, shake the mixture until it is fully suspended, and add 20~uL of proteinase K solution.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.5: Add 200~uL of buffer GB, mix well, and place the micro-centrifuge tube in a thermostat at 70°C for 10min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Measure the DNA concentration using a NanoDrop microspectrophotometer.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Calculate concentration by diluting 50~ng/uL with ddH2O and store in the refrigerator at -20°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Add 29.5~uL of buffer, 2uL each of unlabeled 10uM upstream and downstream primers, 1uL of cellular extracted DNA, and 13~uL of ddH2O to the reaction tube.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Add a 280mmol/L solution of magnesium acetate in a volume of 2.5uL to initiate the reaction.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.3: Uniformly distribute the reaction solution and place it into the PCR instrument at 39°C for 20min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Optimize the reaction time and temperature using B95-8 cell DNA as the template.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Time optimization: vary the reaction time at 5, 10, 15, and 20min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.3: Temperature optimization: vary the reaction temperatures at 35, 37, 39, 41, and 43°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Dilute the previously prepared EBV DNA with a ddH2O gradient to 1×10^6, 1×10^5, 1×10^4, 1×10^3, 1×10^2, 1×10^1, 1×10^0 copies/uL.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Use 1~uL of the diluted DNA for ordinary RPA amplification at 39°C for 15~min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Set up the RPA reaction with a common forward primer, a reverse primer with Biotin labeling, buffer, DNA template, ddH2O, and magnesium acetate.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Add the FITC-labeled probe, nfo enzyme, and nfo enzyme buffer to the reaction product.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.3: Dilute the final amplification product with diluent at a ratio of 1:100 and add 50~uL to the lateral flow strip.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Optimize the reaction time and temperature using 50ng/uL B95-8 cellular DNA as the reaction template.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Time optimization: vary the reaction time of the first step at 5, 10, 15, and 20min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.3: Temperature optimization: vary the reaction temperatures at 35, 37, 39, 41, and 43°C.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.1: Dilute the EBV DNA to 1×10^6, 1×10^5, 1×10^4, 1×10^3, 1×10^2, 1×10^1, 1×10^0 copies/uL in a gradient.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.2: Use 1~uL of each concentration as the template for amplification at 39°C for 15min.

title: A Simple, Rapid, and Cost-Effective Method for Assessing Carbohydrate Partitioning in Microalgae and Arabidopsis thaliana
abstract: Carbohydrates serve crucial functions in most living cells, encompassing structural and metabolic roles. Within the realms of plant and algal biology, carbohydrate biosynthesis and partitioning play pivotal roles in growth, development, stress physiology, and various practical applications. These applications span diverse fields, including the food and feed industry, bioenergetics (biofuels), and environmental management. However, existing methods for carbohydrate determination tend to be costly and time-intensive. In response to that, we propose a novel approach to assess carbohydrate partitioning from small samples. This method leverages the differential solubility of various fractions, including soluble sugars, starch, and structural polymers (such as cellulose). After fractionation, a straightforward spectrophotometric analysis allows for the quantification of sugars.
problem: Existing methods for assessing carbohydrate partitioning in microalgae and plants are costly, time-intensive, and often require large sample volumes, limiting their utility in research and practical applications.
method: Fractionation based on differential solubility of carbohydrate components (soluble sugars, starch, and structural polymers like cellulose), followed by spectrophotometric quantification of sugars.
innovation: Simple, rapid, and cost-effective; requires small sample volumes; eliminates the need for complex equipment or expensive reagents; enables efficient quantification of multiple carbohydrate fractions.
application: Useful in plant and algal biology for studying growth, development, and stress physiology; applicable in industries such as food and feed, bioenergetics (biofuels), and environmental management.
input:
# Biological materials

Chlamydomonas reinhardtii represents a valuable research organism with a sequenced genome, simple life cycle, and ability to grow in multiple metabolic states. It is a model organism for studies in areas like flagella structure, chloroplast biogenesis, photosynthesis, and cell–cell recognition. Its cell wall is composed of glycoproteins and polysaccharides in a multi-layered structure. Strain CC125 represents a popular wild-type (WT) alga for the species; strain cw15 6 is a cell wall–deficient mutant that facilitates genetic manipulation and cellular process studies; and sta6 is a mutant strain deficient in starch accumulation, which is very useful for studies on carbon partitioning and lipid accumulation 7.

Scenedesmus obliquus and Chlorella sorokiniana are thoroughly used for biotechnological applications such as the production of biofuels and food/feed ingredients and wastewater treatment. They show very robust and prolific growth in cultivation facilities. In contrast to C. reinhardtii, they currently offer limited possibilities for genetic modification and reduced availability of mutant strains. While the S. obliquus cell wall comprises a resistant outer layer of algaenan and an inner layer of cellulosic material, the C. sorokiniana cell wall presents a thin trilaminate layer of hemicellulose and a glucosamine-based residue and produces mucilage 8.

A. thaliana, a model organism in plant biology, boasts features like a small genome, rapid life cycle, and easy genetic modification. Its cell wall, composed of cellulose, hemicellulose, and pectin, provides strength, flexibility, and porosity. Some cells even develop a secondary cell wall with lignin for rigidity. Structural proteins, enzymes, and glycoproteins contribute to cell signaling and growth. Remodeling occurs during growth and in response to environmental stress 9.

All of these organisms produce starch as a carbon and energy reserve, and sugars with different physiological roles.

# Organisms' cultivation conditions

The microalgal strains C. . reinhardtii CC125 (WT), cw15 (cell wall–deficient), and sta6 (starchless mutant) were kindly provided by C. Benning (Michigan State University), and strains C. . sorokiniana RP and S. obliquus C1S were isolated 10 and characterized 11 by our research group. These algal strains belong to the INBIOTEC culture collection.

The microalgal strains were cultivated and induced for carbohydrate accumulation as previously described in Bader et al. 12 under nitrogen-deficient conditions.

The A . thaliana used in this study was a wild type of Columbia (Col-O) stored in our laboratory. Seeds were sown in pots and grown under 16/8~h~ light/dark (light 120 umol photons m^-2s^-1 ) at 23~^°C in a growth room. Fourteenday-old A. thaliana plants were treated with 150mMNaCl for 14 days before leaves were collected for carbohydrate analysis.

# Reagents

1.  Distilled water dH_2O)
2. Double-distilled water ddH_2O) for anthrone solution
3. Ethanol 96% ( C_2H_6O) (e.g., Alco Protect, Porta, Argentina)
4. Perchloric acid 60% (HClO4) (Fluka, catalog number: 77232)
5. Sulfuric acid 96%-98% (H_2S O_4) ) (Biopack, Brand, catalog number: 0303A0036)
6. Glucose analytical grade (C_6H_12O_6) (Glc) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: G5767)
7.  Anthrone (C_14H_10O) Fluka, catalog number: A 866 (0740)
8.  Thiourea (CH_4N_2S) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: T7875-500G)
Note: Both sulfuric acid and perchloric acid are hazardous to touch and inhalation; therefore, it is necessary to
work with caution and use personal protective equipment (gloves, lab coat, closed-toe shoes, and safety goggles).

Solutions

For carbohydrate quantification, the anthrone method was used, which has been widely validated and allows for the quantification of a broad range of carbohydrates, hexoses, and aldopentoses 13. In the presence of concentrated sulfuric acid, carbohydrates are dehydrated into furfurals (or hydroxymethylfurfurals), which condense with anthrone (10-keto-9,10-dihydroxyanthracene) (Figure 1) to produce a blue-green complex. The intensity of the color is quantified by absorbance at 620nm .

()
Figure 1. Reaction of the anthrone assay. Modified from Gerwig 14. The extinction coefficient of the complex between 5-hydroxy methyl furfural and anthrone at 620nm is 76,000M^-1c m^-1 .

1. 67% sulfuric acid solution (see Recipes)
2. Anthrone solution ( 72% sulfuric acid final concentration) (see Recipes)
3. 10mM glucose solution (see Recipes)

# Recipes

1. 67% sulfuric acid solution f(10 m L) )

Conduct the process under a fume hood and using personal protective equipment (gloves, lab coat, closed-toe shoes, and safety goggles). In a glass container, pour 3.3~mL of ddH_2O . Place the container on ice and then slowly add 6.7mL of sulfuric acid to prevent acid splashes upon contact with water.

# 2.  Anthrone solution (100mL) )

Conduct the process under a fume hood and using personal protective equipment (gloves, lab coat, closed-toe shoes, and safety goggles). In a glass container, pour 28~mL of ddH_2O . Place the container on ice and then slowly add 35~mL of sulfuric acid to prevent acid splashes upon contact with water, while stirring with a magnetic stir bar. Add 50~mg of anthrone and _~l~g~ of thiourea. Complete with 37~mL of sulfuric acid. Leave to stir for 16h in darkness.

# 3. 10 mM Glc solution 10mL )

Prepare by adding 18mg of Glc to 10mL of ddH_2O .

# Equipment

1. General lab supplies: microtubes, pipettes, tips, tube racks, etc.
2. Block heater (Thermolyne, model: Type 17600 Dri-Bath)
3. Bench-top vortex (Labnet, model: VX100)
4. Benchtop centrifuge for 2~mL tubes at room temperature and 4^°C (Thermo Scientific, model: Sorvall Legend
Micro 21R)
5. Fume Hood (Esco, model: EFA-4UDRVW-8)
6. 5 mL glass test tubes
7. Analytical balance (Sartorius, model: Entris2241-1S)
8. UV/VIS spectrometer (Shimadzu Corp., serial number A114548, 05789)
9.  1 cm Pathlength quartz cuvettes; disposable or glass cuvettes can also be used
10. Gas mask (3M, model: 6899B, filters 3M6003) ) for measuring samples with anthrone
11. Thermostatic water bath for laboratory (Daglef Patz, model: Hor, 18.3867)
12. Magnetic stirring bar and magnetic stirrer (Thermolyne, model: Nuova II)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Use approximately 5-10mg of dry and ground sample or equivalent of fresh sample.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Place the pellet obtained from 1.5mL of culture in a pre-weighed microtube and centrifuge at 6,200×g for 10min.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Discard the supernatant and weigh the tube to calculate the fresh weight.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Dry the pellet at 60°C and weigh until a constant weight is reached.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.4: Perform quantification in triplicate and calculate the average to determine the dry weight to fresh weight ratio.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Resuspend the sample in 250µL of dH2O.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2.1: For microalgae, freeze and thaw the sample three times to break the cells.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2.2: For plant samples, perform cell disruption by maceration or grinding with nitrogen.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Add 250µL of 96% EtOH preheated in a water bath at 50°C and vortex for 30s.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Centrifuge at 2,400×g for 10min and keep the supernatant for sugar quantitation.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3: Repeat steps 1-2 three times for a final volume of 1mL.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Dry the pellet in a thermal block at 50°C for 15min to evaporate the EtOH.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Add 250µL of dH2O, homogenize, and then add 250µL of 60% HClO4. Vortex for 30s.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3: Incubate on ice for 20min to extract starch.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4: Centrifuge at 2,400×g for 10min and keep the supernatant for starch quantification.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5: Repeat steps 2-4 one more time for a final extraction volume of 1mL.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Add 1mL of dH2O to the pellet to rinse the HClO4. Vortex and centrifuge at 6,200×g for 10min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Add 500µL of 67% H2SO4. Vortex for 30s and let stand for 1h. Vortex periodically.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Centrifuge at 16,200×g for 10min and keep the supernatant for structural carbohydrates quantitation.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1: Prepare a 1:10 dilution of the extracts.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2: Take 200µL of dilute extract and add 1mL of anthrone reagent in a 10mL glass tube. Vortex.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3: Boil for 15min in a fume hood and cool to room temperature. Vortex.
hierarchical_protocol.5.5.1: Prepare samples containing from 50 to 400nM Glc.
hierarchical_protocol.5.5.2: Calculate slope (α) and intercept (β) coefficients of the linear regression model.
hierarchical_protocol.5.6: Calculate carbohydrate concentration in every sample and replicate using the equation.

title: A High-Throughput Droplet-based Method to Facilitate Microbial Conjugation
abstract: Droplet microfluidic platforms have been broadly used to facilitate DNA transfer in mammalian and bacterial hosts via methods such as transformation, transfection, and conjugation, as introduced in our previous work. Herein, we recapitulate our method for conjugal DNA transfer between Bacillus subtilis strains in a droplet for increased conjugation efficiency and throughput of an otherwise laborious protocol. By co-incubating the donor and recipient strains in droplets, our method confines cells into close proximity allowing for increased cell-to-cell interactions. This methodology is advantageous in its potential to automate and accelerate the genetic modification of undomesticated organisms that may be difficult to cultivate. This device is also designed for modularity and can be integrated into a variety of experimental workflows in which fine-tuning of donor-to-recipient cell ratios, growth rates, and media substrate concentrations may be necessary.
problem: Traditional microbial conjugation methods are labor-intensive, inefficient, and lack throughput, particularly for undomesticated organisms that are difficult to cultivate.
method: Co-incubation of donor and recipient Bacillus subtilis strains in droplet microfluidic platforms to confine cells in close proximity, enhancing cell-to-cell interactions and conjugation efficiency.
innovation: High-throughput, modular, and automatable droplet-based method that increases conjugation efficiency by optimizing cell-to-cell interactions, reduces labor, and facilitates genetic modifications in undomesticated organisms.
application: Broadly applicable to microbial conjugation studies, particularly for undomesticated organisms, and adaptable to workflows requiring precise control of donor-to-recipient ratios, growth conditions, and media compositions.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Spin coat SU-8 2050 onto a silicon wafer at 2,100rpm.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Apply the first soft baking step at 65°C for 24h.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.3: Apply the second soft baking step at 95°C for 20min.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.4: Expose the coated Si wafer in the photolithography mask aligner using a mask design.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.5: Apply a post-exposure baking step at 65°C for 40min, then 95°C for 20min.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.6: Remove the unexposed photoresist using EBR-10A.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.7: Apply a coating of tridecafluoro-1,1,2,2 tetrahydrooctyl trichlorosilane for 60min.

2.title: Generating the ENTRAP Device Using PDMS

hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Place the silicon wafer mold into a Petri dish or any clean container large enough to fit the silicon wafer.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3: Pour 20g of material over the mold.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4: For ease of removal of the PDMS post-curing, secure the Si-SU-8 master mold to the Petri dish using Kapton tape along the edges of the mold.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5: Allow PDMS to cure over the mold either at room temperature (25°C) overnight on a level surface or at 65°C for 1-4h in an oven.

3.title: Fabricating the Bottom Surface of the Channels

hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Using the PDMS made in step A3, coat a clean glass slide with a thin layer of PDMS (30um thickness) by spin-coating at 3,000rpm for 30s.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Allow this PDMS to cure under the same conditions as in step A3.

4.title: Bonding the ENTRAP Device to the PDMS-Coated Glass Slide and Preparing for Experimentation

hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Carefully, using a scalpel or razor, cut a large rectangle in the PDMS around the channel patterns.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Remove the PDMS rectangle (which contains the channels) from the silicon wafer and place it on the PDMS-coated glass slide.

5.title: Introduce Tubing for the Inlet and Outlets of the Device

hierarchical_protocol.5.1: Use a needle to poke holes in the device where the inlets and outlets are designed.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1: Place the device in the plasma cleaner and apply a 90s plasma treatment at a power of 150W and a pressure of 150mTorr.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1: Streak strains from glycerol stock onto LB agar plates with selection antibiotics.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2: Incubate these streaked agar plates overnight (>14h) at 37°C.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3: Ensure that at least 25mL of LB is available for the entirety of the culturing and dilution process described ahead.
hierarchical_protocol.7.4: Pick a single large colony from the plates and suspend this colony in 3mL of LB liquid media supplemented with the same selection antibiotics that were on the agar media.
hierarchical_protocol.7.5: Culture the donor and recipient strain to an OD600 between 0.8 and 1.2, as read on the spectrophotometer.
hierarchical_protocol.7.6: At this point, subculture these strains into fresh media with the same selection antibiotics (culture volumes: 3-5mL).
hierarchical_protocol.7.7: Allow the donor strain to grow to an OD600 of 0.2; at this point, xylose should be added to the culture to a final concentration of 1%.
hierarchical_protocol.7.8: Culture both strains to an OD600 between 0.8 and 1.0.
hierarchical_protocol.7.9: Pellet cultures by centrifugation at 3,000×g for 3min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.10: Wash pellets with 1mL of PBS and re-centrifuge at 3,000×g for 3min. Repeat twice.
hierarchical_protocol.7.11: Resuspend both pellets in either TSS media (Recipe 1) or LB media supplemented with D-alanine (100mug/mL, to a final OD600 of 0.6.

8.title: Conjugation of Cells in the ENTRAP Device

hierarchical_protocol.8.1: Prior to experimentation, the fully fabricated PDMS DNA ENTRAP microdevices should be baked at 80°C for 4h to ensure a state of ensured hydrophobicity.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2: Combine the donor cells with recipient cells at a 1:1 ratio.
hierarchical_protocol.8.3: Load at least 500uL of the donor/recipient cell mix into a 1mL BD plastic syringe.
hierarchical_protocol.8.4: Prepare the oil phase solution according to Recipe 2. Filter the solution through a 0.2um filter before use.
hierarchical_protocol.8.5: Prime all microfluidic channels and devices with the oil phase solution prior to operation.
hierarchical_protocol.8.6: Load 5mL of the carrier oil/surfactant mixture (Novec 7500/PicoSurf) into a 5mL BD plastic syringe.
hierarchical_protocol.8.7: Place the loaded syringes into separate Chemyx Fusion 200 pumps.
hierarchical_protocol.8.8: Run both syringe pumps to begin droplet formation.
hierarchical_protocol.8.9: While droplets are being formed, you may perform imaging under an inverted optical microscope.
hierarchical_protocol.8.10: You may stop the syringe pumps when you have achieved the desired volume (or expected droplet number).
hierarchical_protocol.8.11: Incubate droplets for at least 1h at ambient temperatures or 37°C (depending on your recipient strain’s culture constraints).
hierarchical_protocol.8.12: After the desired co-incubation period, flow the droplets out from the micro-vessel chip.
hierarchical_protocol.8.13: Pipette 50uL of the droplets that are in oil suspension within the micro-vessel chambers used for conjugation onto a selection agar plate.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1: After the incubation period, inspect the transconjugant plates (plates with 10ug/mL tetracycline) for colonies.
hierarchical_protocol.9.2: Pick several colonies from the transconjugant plate. Inoculate 3mL cultures, supplemented with 10ug/mL tetracycline.
hierarchical_protocol.9.3: When grown to an OD600 of 0.2, induce cells with 1mM IPTG, then shake for 1h at 37°C (or whatever temperature suits your recipient strain).

9.4.title: Various Analyses to Confirm the Successful Conjugation of DNA into the Recipient Strain

hierarchical_protocol.9.4.2: Option 2: Plate reader for fluorescence measurement.

title: Display of Native SARS-CoV-2 Spike on Mammalian Cells to Measure Antibody Affinity and ADCC
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic led to the rapid development of antibody-based therapeutics and vaccines targeting the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. Several antibodies have been instrumental in protecting vulnerable populations, but their utility was limited by the emergence of spike variants with diminished susceptibility to antibody binding and neutralization. Moreover, these spike variants exhibited reduced neutralization by polyclonal antibodies in vaccinated individuals. Accordingly, the characterization of antibody binding to spike variants is critical to define antibody potency and understand the impact of amino acid changes. A key challenge in this effort is poor spike stability, with most current methods assessing antibody binding using individual domains instead of the intact spike or variants with stabilizing amino acid changes in the ectodomain (e.g., 2P or HexaPro). The use of non-native spike may not accurately predict antibody binding if changes lie within the epitope or alter epitope accessibility by altering spike dynamics. Here, we present methods to characterize antibody affinity for and activity against unmodified SARS-CoV-2 spike protein variants displayed on a mammalian cell membrane that recapitulates the native spike environment on infected cells. These include a flow cytometry–based method to determine the effective antibody binding affinity (K_D) and an antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) assay to assess Fc-mediated activities. These methods can readily evaluate antibody activity across a panel of spike variants and contribute to our understanding of spike/antibody co-evolution.
problem: The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 spike variants with reduced susceptibility to antibody binding and neutralization complicates the assessment of antibody potency. Current methods often use non-native or stabilized spike proteins, which may not accurately reflect antibody binding to the native spike.
method: Flow cytometry–based determination of effective antibody binding affinity (K_D) and antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) assays using unmodified native SARS-CoV-2 spike protein displayed on mammalian cell membranes.
innovation: Recapitulation of the native spike environment on infected cells, enabling accurate assessment of antibody binding and Fc-mediated activities without stabilizing mutations or non-native constructs.
application: Evaluation of antibody affinity and activity across a panel of SARS-CoV-2 spike variants, critical for understanding spike/antibody co-evolution and informing therapeutic and vaccine development.

1.title: Part I: Determine Effective Antibody KD

1.1.title: Transfect Expi293F Cells for Spike Display (Day 0-1)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Thaw and grow Expi293F cells for at least one week after thawing.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.3: Determine the number of cells required for the experiment and seed 1.5 times that number at 2.5 x 10^6 cells/mL.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.4: Incubate cells at 37°C and 8% CO2 with shaking at 125 rpm.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.5: Next day, repeat step A2 to determine cell count and viability.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.6: Dilute cells to 2.5 x 10^6 cells/mL and seed the appropriate number of cells calculated in step A3.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.7: Calculate the amount of DNA and other reagents necessary for the experiment.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.8: Combine pEGFP plasmid and pWT-SARS-2 plasmid in OptiMEM.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.9: Dilute ExpiFectamine 293 reagent in fresh OptiMEM.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.10: Add the diluted ExpiFectamine to the diluted DNA and mix gently.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.11: Add DNA-ExpiFectamine 293 mixture dropwise to the diluted cells and gently swirl to mix.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.12: Incubate cells in an incubator at 37°C and 8% CO2 with shaking at 125 rpm for 48 hours.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: On day 2 post-transfection, count the transfected or mock-transfected cells using a hemocytometer or automated cell counter.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Determine the number of cells needed for the experiment and transfer 1.5 times the calculated number to a 15 mL conical tube.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.4: Count cells and dilute to 1.2 x 10^7 cells/mL in staining buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.5: Dilute test antibody and controls in a fresh dilution plate.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.6: Aliquot 25 uL of diluted cells per sample in a fresh 96-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.7: Transfer 25 uL of stain from the stain dilution plate to appropriate wells of cells, mix gently, and incubate for 1 hour on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.9: Incubate cells with 50 uL of 1:250 goat anti-human-Fc-PE in staining buffer for 1 hour on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.10: Repeat step B8 with the final resuspension in 200 uL of staining buffer or the volume required for analysis on the flow cytometer used.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Collect data on a flow cytometer.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Gating strategy: cells, singlets, EGFP+ cells.

2.1.title: Transfection of 293T Cells with Spike and EGFP Plasmids (Day 0-1)

hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Seed cells such that there is a single flask prepared on the day of transfection at 70-90% confluency for each spike variant or control tested.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.3: Dilute 1 ug of DNA per milliliter of culture volume and 2 uL of P3000 reagent per milliliter of culture volume into 50 uL of OptiMEM per milliliter of culture volume.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.4: Dilute 2.5 uL of Lipofectamine 3000 reagent per milliliter of culture volume into 50 uL of OptiMEM per milliliter of culture volume.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.5: Gently pipette diluted DNA/P3000 mixture into the tube containing diluted Lipofectamine 3000, mix gently, and let sit for 10-15 minutes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.6: Slowly add the DNA/Lipofectamine 3000 mixture in a dropwise manner to the prepared flask of 293T cells.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.8: The next day, remove media and replace with fresh 293T growth medium.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Passage NK-92 cells using NK growth media.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: One day after transfecting the 293T cells, centrifuge the NK-92 cells and aspirate the media.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: Replace with fresh NK-92 media, add fresh IL-2, and incubate overnight at 37°C.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4: On the day of the assay, count the cells and resuspend them in NK-92 growth media without FBS to a concentration of 2 x 10^6 cells/mL.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: On day 2, remove media from 293T cells and wash with one culture volume of PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Remove PBS, add one culture volume of PBS with 10 mM EDTA, and incubate for approximately 10 minutes or until cells detach from the flask surface.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: When cells are released from the plate, add 2-3 mL of complete 293T growth media per milliliter of original culture and transfer to a 15 mL conical tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.4: Spin cells at 250 x g for 5 minutes, remove supernatant, and resuspend in serum-free 293T growth media.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.5: Pipette cells up and down vigorously 10 times with a 1 mL Pipetman or similar to disrupt cell clumps.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.6: Count cells, determine viability, and dilute in serum-free 293T growth media to a concentration of 0.5-1 x 10^6 cells/mL.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.7: Add calcein-AM to the transfected cells to a final concentration of 2 uM, invert the tube several times to mix, wrap in foil, and incubate at 37°C for 30 minutes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.8: Wash transfected 293T cells three times with at least double the original culture volume of serum-free 293T growth media.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.9: Resuspend transfected 293T cells in 1 mL of serum-free 293T growth media, count, and dilute cells to 1 x 10^5 cells/mL.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.10: Prepare 4x final concentration antibody stock in microcentrifuge tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.11: To each well in a 96-well plate: add 100 uL of transfected 293T cells, add 50 uL of antibody from the dilution plate, and add 50 uL of NK-92 cells.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Remove the plate from the incubator and carefully add 100 uL of lysis buffer to the maximum lysis control wells.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Spin the plate at 400 x g for 10 minutes and transfer 100 uL of supernatant to a fresh black clear-bottom 96-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.3: Using a plate reader, measure the fluorescence intensity at an excitation wavelength of 488 nm and emission wavelength of 515 nm.

title: Utilizing the Planar Lipid Bilayer Technique to Investigate Drosophila melanogaster dMpv17 Channel Activity
abstract: The planar lipid bilayer (PLB) technique represents a highly effective method for the study of membrane protein properties in a controlled environment. The PLB method was employed to investigate the role of mitochondrial inner membrane protein 17 (MPV17), whose mutations are associated with a hepatocerebral form of mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome (MDS). This protocol presents a comprehensive, step-by-step guide to the assembly and utilization of a PLB system. The procedure comprises the formation of a lipid bilayer over an aperture, the reconstitution of the target protein, and the utilization of electrophysiological recording techniques to monitor channel activity. Furthermore, recommendations are provided for optimizing experimental conditions and overcoming common challenges encountered in PLB experiments. Overall, this protocol highlights the versatility of the PLB technique in advancing our understanding of membrane protein function and its broad application in various fields of research.
problem: Understanding the role of mitochondrial inner membrane protein 17 (MPV17), whose mutations are linked to mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome (MDS), requires precise methods to study its channel activity in a controlled environment.
method: The planar lipid bilayer (PLB) technique is employed, which involves forming a lipid bilayer over an aperture, reconstituting the target protein (MPV17), and using electrophysiological recording techniques to monitor channel activity.
innovation: PLB provides a highly controlled environment to study membrane protein properties, enabling precise characterization of channel activity and overcoming challenges in traditional methods.
application: This protocol is broadly applicable for investigating membrane protein function, particularly MPV17, and can be adapted to study other membrane proteins in various research fields, including mitochondrial disorders.

Figure 1. Bilayer workstation. (A) The bilayer workstation used for dMpv17 experiments. (B) Graphical representation of bilayer workstation. The planar lipid bilayer workstation consists of (1) a Faraday cage positioned on an anti-vibration isolation table (2), (3) a bilayer clamp amplifier (e.g., BC-525, Warner Instruments Corporation), (4) a digitizer (e.g., Digidata 1322A, Axon Instruments), a 16-bit device connected to the current and voltage outputs and to a data acquisition system, and (5) a personal computer with an acquisition program (e.g., pCLAMP program sets) for data acquisition.
