hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Prepare a cold solution of sodium nitrite (106 mg, 1.5 mmol) by dissolving it in 385 µL of water.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Prepare a cold solution of 2-Amino-5-nitrophenol (200 mg, 1.3 mmol) in 648 µL of HCl.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.3: Slowly add the cold sodium nitrite solution dropwise to the cold 2-Amino-5-nitrophenol solution while maintaining the mixture on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.4: Stir the mixture for 1 h at -5 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.5: Add sodium chloride to the ice to maintain the temperature at -5 °C or lower.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.6: Prepare a solution of stannous chloride (931 mg, 4.1 mmol) by dissolving it in 927 µL of cold HCl.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.7: Slowly add the stannous chloride solution to the reaction mixture while maintaining the low temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.8: Mix the reaction for 1 h at -5 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.9: Vacuum filter the mixture and wash the precipitate with cold methanol and diethyl ether.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Stir 2Hzin5NP (400 mg, 2.36 mmol) and salicylaldehyde (2.5 mL, 23.6 mmol) in 19 mL of MeOH for 1 h at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Cool the reaction mixture in an ice bath and then filter the mixture.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Wash the solid product with cold MeOH and dry it under vacuum.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Stir 2Hzin5NP (90 mg, 0.53 mmol) and acetaldehyde (29 µL, 0.44 mmol) in 2.4 mL of EtOH for 1 h at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Cool the reaction mixture in an ice bath, then filter the mixture.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.3: Wash the solid product with cold EtOH and dry it under vacuum.

2.title: Protocol for Rf Calculation Using Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC)

hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Draw a baseline approximately 1 cm from the bottom edge of the TLC plate using a pencil.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Mark the spots where you will apply the sample along the baseline.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Apply a small drop of each sample dissolved in methanol onto the marked spots on the baseline using a capillary tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Allow the spots to dry before proceeding.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Fill the developing chamber with a small amount of solvent (mobile phase) to a depth of approximately 0.5 cm.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Place the TLC plate in the developing chamber, ensuring that the baseline remains above the solvent level.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Allow the solvent to rise up the plate by capillary action until it reaches approximately 1-2 cm below the top edge of the plate.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Examine the plate under UV light or use a suitable staining reagent to visualize the spots.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Mark the center of each visible spot with a pencil.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.3: Measure the distance from the baseline to the center of each spot and the distance from the baseline to the solvent front.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.4: Calculate the Rf value for each compound using the formula: Rf = Distance traveled by the compound / Distance traveled by the solvent.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Culture HDF, A-498, and ACHN cells in DMEM containing 4.5 g/L glucose, 1 mmol/L sodium pyruvate, and 200 mM L-glutamine supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% penicillin-streptomycin.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Maintain them in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2 at 37 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.3: Subculture them using a trypsin-EDTA solution (0.05%) when they reach 80% confluency.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Subculture A498, ACHN, and HDF cells when they reach approximately 80% cell confluency.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Discard the media, rinse the cell monolayer with PBS, and incubate the cells with 25% Trypsin / 5 mM EDTA solution in PBS (pH 7.4) at 37 °C for 5 min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.3: Mix the detached cell suspension with 10% FBS (v/v) complete DMEM and centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 × g for 5 min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Use a hemocytometer for cell counting.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Load a 10 µL aliquot of the cell suspension into the square of the hemocytometer.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.3: Count the cells three times, focusing on the center of the square under the inverted light microscope using a 20 × objective lens.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.4: Calculate the cell concentration using the equation: Cell number / mL = Number of counted cells × Dilution factor / mm^2 × Chamber depth.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.1: Suspend the cells with a freezing mixture consisting of 10% (v/v) DMSO in heat-inactivated FBS.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.2: Suspend approximately 1 × 10^6 cells in 1 mL of the freezing mixture and transfer the suspension into a cryovial.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.3: Place the cryovials in a -80 °C freezer for at least 16 h, then transfer the cryovials into a liquid nitrogen tank for long-term storage.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.1: Retrieve the cryopreserved cells from either the liquid nitrogen tank or the -80 °C freezer and quickly warm them up to 37 °C in a water bath.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.2: Add the cell suspension dropwise into complete DMEM to prevent cell disruption due to the osmotic pressure difference between the freezing mixture and the medium.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.3: Centrifuge the cell suspension at 300 × g for 5 min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.4: Discard the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in 5 mL of complete DMEM.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Seed HDF (5,000 cells/well), A-498 (10,000 cells/well), and ACHN (10,000 cells/well) cells in 100 µL into 96-well plates and allow them to adhere overnight (16 h).
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Treat the cells with H2O2 (0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, and 2.5 mM) in FBS-free DMEM for 2 h and wash the cells with serum-free media to remove H2O2.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.3: Incubate cells with 2Hzin5NP (5, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 50 µM) in PBS (pH 7.4) for 30 min at 37 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Remove the media, wash the cells thrice with PBS (5 min washes), and then incubate them with DMEM at 37 °C for 24 h.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Assess the effects of H2O2 and subsequent 2Hzin5NP treatment on cell proliferation using the WST-1 assay, following the manufacturer’s instructions.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.3: Measure absorbance values at 450 and 650 nm using a Varioskan Lux multimode microplate reader.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.4: Calculate the percentage of cell viability by normalizing the values to non-treated control cells, which should be adjusted to 100% using the formula: Asample × 100 / Acontrol.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Pre-treat HDF, A-498, and ACHN cells with increasing concentrations of sodium pyruvate (0, 1, and 2 mM) in complete DMEM for 1 h at 37 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Treat the cells with 2 mM H2O2 in FBS-free medium at 37 °C for 2 h.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.3: Incubate A-498 cells with 20 µM 2Hzin5NP, while subjecting ACHN and HDF cells to 15 µM 2Hzin5NP in PBS for 30 min.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Image the cells using a Zeiss LSM 800 confocal microscope at room temperature after washing them once with PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Excite the samples using diode 405 and 488 lasers and collect the emission using long pass (LP) 435 and 518 filters.

6.title: Quantification of Carbonylation in Cell Lysate

hierarchical_protocol.6.1.1: Collect cell pellets from HDF, A-498, and ACHN cells and suspend them in 500 µL of lysis buffer containing 0.05 mM PMSF and a protease inhibitor cocktail dissolved in dH2O.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1.2: Lyse the cells by subjecting them to six consecutive freeze-thaw cycles using liquid nitrogen and a water bath at 37 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1.3: Determine the protein content using the DC protein assay following the manufacturer’s instructions.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.1: Measure the fluorescence intensity of H2O2-treated and labeled cell lysates using a Varioskan Lux multimode microplate reader with excitation wavelength set at 396 nm and emission wavelength set at 502 nm.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.1: Seed A498, ACHN, and HDF cells at a density of 10,000 cells/well, and HDF cells at a density of 5,000 cells/well into a 96-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.3: Treat the cells with 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, and 2.5 mM H2O2 in FBS-free standard DMEM for 120 min.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.1: Plate A498, ACHN, and HDF cells at a density of 10,000 cells/well, and HDF cells at a density of 5,000 cells/well into a 96-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.2: Incubate the cells for 9 h and treat the cells with 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 50 µM 2Hzin5NP in PBS (pH 7.4) for 30 min at 37 °C.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.1: Label cells with DCFDA (2′,7′-dichlorofluorescin diacetate), a cellular reactive oxygen species detection assay kit.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.2: Count A498 and ACHN cells, seed them into a 96-well plate at a density of 10,000 cells/well, and incubate for 24 h.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.3: Incubate A498 cells with the maximum non-toxic dose of H2O2 at 2.5 mM, and ACHN cells with the maximum non-toxic dose of H2O2 at 2 mM in FBS-free standard DMEM for 120 min.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.1: Warm-up period: Turn on the FluoroMax-4 and allow it to warm up for at least 30 min prior to use.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.2: Automatic calibration: The FluoroMax-4 automatically calibrates itself upon startup.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.3: Baseline check with water sample: Before beginning any analyses, run a water sample to verify that the fluorescence spectrum is correctly set and that there are no unexpected peaks or noise.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.1: Warm-up period: Turn on the UV-Vis spectrophotometer and allow it to warm up for at least 30 min before use.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.2: Blank measurement: Before analyzing the actual sample, run a blank measurement using the same solvent as the sample.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.3: Sample analysis: After recording the blank, proceed with the analysis of your sample.
hierarchical_protocol.8.3.1: Acquire absorption spectra using an Agilent/HP 8453 UV-Visible spectrophotometer.
hierarchical_protocol.8.3.2: Record emission spectra at room temperature using a Jobin Yvon Horiba FluoroMax-4 spectrofluorometer.
hierarchical_protocol.8.4.1: Determine fluorescence quantum yields (PhiF) in dilute solutions with an absorbance below 0.1 at the excitation wavelength.
hierarchical_protocol.8.4.2: Use quinine sulfate in 0.1 M H2SO4 as the standard.
hierarchical_protocol.8.4.3: Calculate the quantum yields using the equation: PhiF = PhiR (AR / AS) (PhiS / A).
hierarchical_protocol.8.5.1: Run the 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra for the synthesized molecules using an AVANCE III 500 MHz spectrometer (Bruker).
hierarchical_protocol.8.5.2: Use TMS as the internal standard.
hierarchical_protocol.8.5.3: Denote chemical shift multiplicities using the following abbreviations: s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, m = multiplet.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1.1: Obtain all data from three independent experiments and present them as the mean ± SD (with error bars) for clarity.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1.2: Analyze the quantification of carbonylation in cell lysates using a two-tailed student t-test.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1.3: Consider a p-value less than 0.05 as statistically significant.

title: Optimized Isolation of LysosomeRelated Organelles from Stationary Phase and Iron-Overloaded Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Cells
abstract: Lysosome-related organelles (LROs) are a class of heterogeneous subcellular organelles conserved in eukaryotes, performing various functions. An important function of LROs is to mediate phosphorus and metal homeostasis. Chlamydomonas reinhardtii serves as a model organism for investigating metal ion metabolism. Considering that LROs contain polyphosphate and various metal elements, the purification strategy is based on their higher density by fractionating cell lysate through OptiPrep density gradient ultracentrifugation. Here, we optimized a method for purifying LROs from C. reinhardtii cells that have reached stationary phase (sta-LROs) or are overloaded with iron (Fe-LROs). Our protocol provides technical support for further investigations on the biogenesis and function of LROs in C. reinhardtii.
problem: Need for an efficient method to isolate lysozyme-related organelles (LROs) from Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, particularly from stationary-phase and iron-overloaded cells, to study their role in phosphorus and metal homeostasis.
method: Fractionation of cell lysate using OptiPrep density gradient ultracentrifugation, leveraging the higher density of LROs for their purification.
innovation: Optimized purification technique tailored for isolating LROs from specific physiological states (stationary phase and iron overload) in C. reinhardtii, enabling detailed functional and biogenesis studies.
application: Facilitates research on LRO biogenesis and function, particularly in metal ion metabolism and phosphorus homeostasis in C. reinhardtii, a model organism for eukaryotic metal ion studies.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Inoculate cell wall–deficient strain cwl5 cells grown on a TAP plate into two flasks containing 300mL of TAP medium.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Culture the cells at 24°C with shaking (180rpm) under continuous illumination (25μmol/m²s) for 6 days.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Inoculate 5-6mL of 2-day-old cwl5 cells, cultured in revised TAP medium, into two flasks containing 300mL of iron-limited TAP medium (0.2μM Fe).
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Culture the cells under continuous light for 5 days with shaking (180rpm) until the cell density reaches 3-5×10^6 cells/mL.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Culture cells for another 26-28 hours in iron-overloading TAP medium (200μM Fe).
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Collect the cells from each flask (600mL in total) by centrifugation at 3,500×g for 3 minutes.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Discard the supernatant and wash the pellets once with 100mL of IB buffer by resuspending with a pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3: Discard the supernatant again and resuspend the total pellets in 15mL of IB buffer supplemented with a complete protease inhibitor cocktail and 2mM DTT.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4: Disrupt the cells by squeezing them through a syringe with a 25G needle three times, ensuring most cells are opened without disrupting the chloroplast structure.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Adjust the volume of each sample to 70mL with IB buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Centrifuge the samples at 10,000×g for 10 minutes at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellets in 4mL of 34% OptiPrep (add 8μL of DTT and 40μL of protein inhibitor cocktail before use).
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Prepare a discontinuous OptiPrep gradient with 1mL each of 15%, 24%, 34% (with samples), 37%, and 40% OptiPrep.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4: Centrifuge the gradient at 50,000×g in a Beckman MLS-50 rotor for 60 minutes at 4°C, setting the acceleration to the maximum level and the deceleration to coast.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Discard the supernatant and resuspend the total sta-LROs with 2mL of 40% OptiPrep (add 4μL of DTT and 20μL of protein inhibitor cocktail before use).
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Prepare a discontinuous OptiPrep gradient with 1mL each of IB buffer, 27%, 40% (with samples), 60%, and 80% OptiPrep.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Centrifuge the gradient at 50,000×g in a Beckman MLS-50 rotor for 60 minutes at 4°C, setting the acceleration to the maximum level and the deceleration to coast.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.1: Collect each layer (L1: layer between 40% and 60%, L2: layer between 60% and 80%) and the pellet below 80% (P2) in 1.5mL Eppendorf tubes, fill to 1.5mL with IB buffer, and mix by repeated pipetting.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.3: Discard the supernatant; pellets are subgroups of sta-LROs separated by different densities.

title: Fast and High-Resolution Imaging of Pollinated Stigmatic Cells by Tabletop Scanning Electron Microscopy
abstract: In plants, the first interaction between the pollen grain and the epidermal cells of the stigma is crucial for successful reproduction. When the pollen is accepted, it germinates, producing a tube that transports the two sperm cells to the ovules for fertilization. Confocal microscopy has been used to characterize the behavior of stigmatic cells postpollination 1, but it is time-consuming since it requires the development of a range of fluorescent marker lines. Here, we propose a quick, high-resolution imaging protocol using tabletop scanning electron microscopy. This technique does not require prior sample fixation or fluorescent marker lines. It effectively captures pollen grain behavior from early hydration (a few minutes after pollination) to pollen tube growth within the stigma (1 h after pollination) and is particularly efficient for tracking pollen tube paths.
problem: Imaging post-pollination events in stigmatic cells is time-consuming with confocal microscopy due to the need for fluorescent marker lines and sample preparation.
method: Tabletop scanning electron microscopy (SEM) for high-resolution imaging of pollen grain behavior and pollen tube growth without prior fixation or fluorescent markers.
innovation: Eliminates the need for sample fixation and fluorescent markers, provides rapid and high-resolution imaging, and captures dynamic processes from pollen hydration to tube growth.
application: Suitable for studying pollen-stigma interactions, pollen tube growth, and fertilization processes in plant reproductive biology, particularly for researchers requiring fast and detailed imaging.
input:
Biological materials

1.  Arabidopsis thaliana, ecotype Columbia Col-0 plants with flowers at stages 12–15 4 in individual pots

# Other materials

1. Straight fine tweezers (Dumont, model: Inox 8)
2. Double-sided black tape (Synergie4, model: DEN-77816)
3. Wood sticks and soft plant ties to stack the plants
4. Sewing thread to tag the emasculated pistils

# Equipment

1.  Tabletop scanning electron microscope (Hirox, model: SH-3000)
2.  Stereomicroscope (Nikon, model: SMZ645, total magnification from 8× to 50× ; eyepieces 10)

# Software and datasets

1.  ImageJ software (1.54c, 2024)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Germinate a few Arabidopsis thaliana seeds, accession Col0, in 0.25L plastic pots containing a peat-based compost with 60kg/m^3 of clay.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: After one week, remove plantlets to keep one plant per pot to facilitate manipulation during emasculation and pollination.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3: Maintain plants in a growth chamber under long-day conditions (16h light, 120-150 umolm^-2s^-1/8h dark at 21°C/19°C) with a relative humidity of around 60%.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4: Water plants throughout their growth cycle and add fertilizer (N/P/K: 18/10/18) to the watering water (4mL/L) once a week.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Water the plant thoroughly the day before emasculation to ensure turgid stigmas and pollen.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Perform flower emasculation the day before pollination and imaging at room temperature (around 22°C).
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Position the plant in its culture pot under a stereomicroscope.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Bend the plant's inflorescences and gently clamp a flower bud at the end of stage 12 between the thumb and the forefinger.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Remove flowers older than stage 12 to minimize the risk of cross-pollination and younger buds to facilitate access to the stage-12 bud.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Carefully open the flower bud to expose the stigma and verify that anthers are not dehiscent.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.3: Remove the anthers, petals, and sepals, and ensure that no pollen grains remain on the stigma papillae.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Label the emasculated pistil with a sewing thread attached at the base of the bare pistil.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Stake the plants using wood sticks and soft plant ties to support their stems.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Return the plants to the culture room and ensure they are well-watered to maintain turgescence in the stigma and pollen.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Collect a single dehiscent anther from a non-emasculated flower bud with tweezers.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Carefully brush the stigma with the anther, depositing only a small amount of pollen grains.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Leave the pollinated plants at room temperature on the bench.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Wait 10-15 minutes to image pollen hydration or 30-60 minutes to image long pollen tubes.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1: Cut the pollinated pistils transversally in the middle of the ovary using fine tweezers at the designated time post-pollination.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2: Ensure the sample height does not exceed 0.5cm to fit into the microscope chamber.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.1: Gently deposit two or three cut pistils vertically onto a 4x2 cm double-sided tape positioned on the SEM platform.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.2: Maintain a minimum distance of 1cm between the pistils.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.1: Place the platform in the Hirox SEM SH-3000, ensuring the door of the SEM is well sealed.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.2: Select temperature (-20°C) and wait until that temperature is reached.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.3: Select accelerating voltage: 15kV and turn on the vacuum.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.1: Observe samples within the first 15 minutes to prevent cells from collapsing during imaging.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.2: Use the AutoFocus button for a quick initial screening and adjust the focus, contrast, and brightness.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.1: Acquire images of the pollinated stigmas.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.2: This method allows for imaging of the pollen hydration stage, pollen tube germination, and tube paths.

title: Preparation of Polarity-Marked Microtubules Using a Plus-End Capping DARPin
abstract: The eukaryotic cytoskeleton is formed in part by microtubules, which are relatively rigid filaments with inherent structural polarity. One consequence of this polarity is that the two ends of a microtubule have different properties with important consequences for their cellular roles. These differences are often challenging to probe within the crowded environment of the cell. Fluorescence microscopy–based in vitro assays with purified proteins and stabilized microtubules have been used to characterize polarity-dependent and end-specific behaviors. These assays require ways to visualize the polarity of the microtubules, which has previously been achieved either by the addition of fluorescently tagged motor proteins with known directionality or by fluorescently polarity marking the microtubules themselves. However, classical polarity-marking protocols require a particular chemically modified tubulin and generate microtubules with chemically different plus and minus segments. These chemical differences in the segments may affect the behavior of interacting proteins of interest in an undesirable manner. We present here a new protocol that uses a previously characterized, reversibly binding microtubule plus-end capping protein, a designed ankyrin repeat protein (DARPin), to efficiently produce polarity-marked microtubules with different fluorescently labeled, but otherwise biochemically identical, plus- and minus-end segments.
problem: Challenges in directly probing the polarity of microtubules within cellular environments and limitations of classical polarity-marking protocols, which introduce chemical differences that may affect the behavior of interacting proteins.
method: Use of a designed ankyrin repeat protein (DARPin) as a reversibly binding microtubule plus-end capping protein to generate polarity-marked microtubules with distinct fluorescent labels but identical biochemical properties.
innovation: Eliminates chemical differences between plus and minus segments, ensures biochemical uniformity, and provides a reversible and efficient method to mark microtubule polarity without interfering with interacting proteins.
application: Enables precise in vitro studies of polarity-dependent and end-specific behaviors of microtubules using fluorescence microscopy, applicable in cytoskeleton research and studies of microtubule-associated proteins.
input:
# Reagents

1.  Porcine brain tubulin, prepared as previously reported 35,36
2.  Purified tandem DARPin D1 protein (D1)_2 , expressed in E. coli and purified according to standard DARPin expression and purification protocols 37,38. A detailed description of the (D1)2 expression on a 500mL scale and purification via metal affinity chromatography and size exclusion chromatography can be found here 14,32. The bacterial (D1)_2 expression plasmid can be requested from A. Plückthun (plueckthun@bioc.uzh.ch)
3.  Fluorescently labeled porcine brain tubulin (i.e., AlexaFluor647 or Atto647-labeled) prepared as previously reported 21,35 Note: Fluorescence labeling ratio should be determined by Nanodrop prior to starting the protocol.
4. Optional for neutravidin-biotin-based immobilization in, e.g., TIRF microscopy assays: biotinylated porcine brain tubulin, prepared as previously reported 21,35
5. Piperazine- .N N -bis(2-ethanesulfonic acid) (PIPES) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: P6757)
6. Magnesium chloride (MgCl_2) , 1M (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: 63069)
7. Ethylene glycol-bis  -aminoethyl ether)-  N,N,N^,N^ -tetraacetic acid (EGTA) (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: E3889)
8. Guanosine- .5^ - (a,z) -methylenotriphosphate (GMPCPP), 10mM (Jena bioscience, catalog number: NU-405)
9.  High-quality purified water, e.g., Millipore Milli-Q

# For gliding assay:

1.  An active, directional microtubule motor protein; we had the minus-end-directed HSET motor protein available in the laboratory, prepared as previously published 39. Many other microtubule motors with established polarity, such as the plus-end directed kinesin-1 or its motor-domain truncations, can be used instead
2. Poly(L-lysine)-polyethylene glycol (PLL-PEG) SuSoS, catalog number: PLL(20)-g3.5- PEG(2)
3.  -Mercaptoethanol  -ME), 14.3M (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: M6250)
4. . -casein (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: C6905)
5.  ATP (Sigma-Aldrich, catalog number: A6419)

# Solutions

1. EGTA, 0.5M , pH 8 (see Recipes)
2. BRB80, 5× stock (see Recipes)
3. BRB80, 1× (see Recipes)
For gliding assay:
1.  PLL-PEG, 2mg/mL (see Recipes)
2.  -casein, 25mg/mL (see Recipes)
3. ATP, 100mM , pH 7 (see Recipes)
4. Gliding buffer (see Recipes)

# Recipes

Note: All solutions should be prepared using high-quality purified water, e.g., Millipore Milli-Q.

1.  EGTA, 0.5 M, pH 8 Add solid KOH to dissolve EGTA powder and adjust p H only by adding KOH, being careful not to overshoot; store at room temperature.

# 2. BRB80, 5× (50 mL)

()

Filter ?0.22 um pore size) and store for up to 4 weeks at 4^°C . Note: PIPES dissolves upon the addition of solid KOH. MgCl2 and EGTA should be added only after PIPES is dissolved (requiring I.35 g of KOH for these amounts). The final pH should be adjusted only by addition of KOH, being careful not to overshoot, to control the total ionic strength of the solution.

3.  BRB80, 1× Diluted from the above recipe on the day of use; keep on ice.

4. PLL-PEG, 2 mg/mL , in water Aliquot and store at -20~^°C .

5.  -casein, 25 mg/mL , in BRB80 Ultracentrifuge, aliquot, snap-freeze in liquid nitrogen, and store at -80~^°C .

6. ATP, 100~mM , pH 7 Filter, aliquot, and store at -80~^°C .

7.  Gliding buffer BRB80 with 5 mM  -ME, 1 mM ATP, 1~mg/mL  -casein; prepare on the day of the experiments and keep at room temperature.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Thaw aliquots of frozen unlabeled tubulin, fluorescent tubulin, and (optionally) biotinylated tubulin.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Prepare a mixture of 3uM total tubulin in BRB 80 1×, supplemented with 0.5mM GMPCPP, including fluorescent tubulin at a final labeling ratio of 3%-5% and (optionally) 18% biotinylated tubulin, with a total volume of 200~uL in a microcentrifuge tube.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Incubate mixture on ice for 5 min.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Transfer the tube to 37°C and incubate for 1h.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.3: Dilute seeds with 170~uL of warm BRB80 1× and centrifuge at 17,000×g for 10min at room temperature in the tabletop microcentrifuge.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Wash the pellet by adding 400~uL of warm BRB80 1× and centrifuging again at 17,000×g for 10min at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.3: Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 50uL of warm BRB80 1×.

2.title: Bright GMPCPP-stabilized minus-end extensions using DARPin (D1)_2

hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Thaw an aliquot of DARPin (D1)_2 and dilute to 2.5uM in BRB80 1× on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Prepare a new “bright” mixture of 3~uM total tubulin in BRB 80 1×, supplemented with 0.5~mM GMPCPP, including fluorescent tubulin at a final labeling ratio of 10%-15% and (optionally) 18% biotinylated tubulin, with a total volume of 200~uL in a microcentrifuge tube.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Incubate the “bright” mixture on ice for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Add 2~uL of the DARPin (D1)_2 dilution to 8~uL of the previously prepared dimly-labeled microtubules at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Dilute the “bright” mixture with 200~uL of cold BRB80 1×.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Transfer 90~uL of the diluted “bright” mixture to 37°C and incubate for 1 min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Add the 10~uL DARPin (D1)2/dim seed mixture directly to the warmed “bright” mixture.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.3: Dilute seeds with 170~uL of warm BRB80 1× and centrifuge at 17,000×g for 10min at room temperature in the tabletop microcentrifuge.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2: Wash the pellet by adding 400~uL of warm BRB80 1× and centrifuging again at 17,000×g for 10min at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.3: Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 50uL of warm BRB80 1×.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Using a fluorescent microscope, quickly prepare a 16~uL dilution of the microtubules and “squash” the dilution between a coverslip and slide.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Fluorescence imaging will readily show how many of the dim stabilized microtubules have a single bright extension.

4.title: Gliding assay to determine correct polarity labeling

4.1.title: Preparation of the Gliding Assay Chamber

hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Place two strips of the double-sided tape on a standard microscopy slide about 5mm apart.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Pipette 10~uL of 2~mg/mL PLL-PEG between the two strips of tape and spread to all the edges using a pipette tip.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Rinse thoroughly with MilliQ water and dry using pressurized air.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.1: Cut a #1.5:22×22:mm coverslip into four equal squares.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.2: Remove the protective tape backing and place one of the coverslip pieces on top, pressing down firmly over the tape to ensure proper adhesion.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3.3: Use 50~uL of gliding buffer to wash the chamber, using filter paper to pull the solution through, and incubate with gliding buffer for 3 min at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.1: Dilute the motor protein, e.g., the minus-end-directed kinesin-14 HSET, to 100nM in gliding buffer.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.2: Dilute the polarity-marked seeds 1:6 with room temperature gliding buffer and flow 50uL into the chamber.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4.3: Seal the chamber ends with KoralisonTM paste.
hierarchical_protocol.4.5: Image fluorescent microtubules at the microscope, using a 5 s interval between frames to capture gliding events over the course of 20 min.

title: Multiplex Genome Editing of Human Pluripotent Stem Cells Using Cpf1
abstract: Targeted genome editing of human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) is critical for basic and translational research and can be achieved with site-specific endonucleases. Cpf1 (CRISPR from Prevotella and Francisella) is a programmable DNA endonuclease with AT-rich PAM sequences. In this protocol, we describe procedures for using a single vector system to deliver Cpf1 and CRISPR RNA (crRNA) for genome editing in hPSCs. This protocol enables indel formation and homologous recombination–mediated precise editing at multiple loci. With the delivery of Cpf1 and a single U6 promoter-driven guide RNA array composed of an AAVS1-targeting and a MAFB-targeting crRNA array, efficient multiplex genome editing at the AAVS1 (knockin) and MAFB (knockout) loci in hPSCs could be achieved in a single experiment. The edited hPSCs expressed pluripotency markers and could differentiate into neurons in vitro. This system also generated INS reporter hPSCs with a 6 kb cassette knockin at the INS locus. The INS reporter cells can differentiate into  -cells that express tdTomato and luciferase, permitting fluorescenceactivated cell sorting of hPSC-  -cells. By targeted screening of potential off-target sequences that are most homologous to crRNA sequences, no off-target mutations were detected in any of the tested sequences. This work provides an efficient and flexible system for precise genome editing in mammalian cells including hPSCs with the benefits of less off-target effects.
problem: Need for efficient and precise multiplex genome editing in human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) for basic research and translational applications, while minimizing off-target effects and simplifying the delivery process.
method: Use of a single vector system delivering Cpf1 (CRISPR from Prevotella and Francisella) and a U6 promoter-driven guide RNA array for simultaneous editing of multiple loci in hPSCs, enabling both indel formation and homologous recombination-mediated precise editing.
innovation: Utilization of Cpf1 with AT-rich PAM sequences for targeted editing, efficient multiplex editing of multiple loci in a single experiment, reduced off-target effects, and compatibility with reporter gene knockin for functional screening and cell sorting.
application: Genome editing in hPSCs for basic and translational research, generation of reporter cell lines (e.g., INS reporter hPSCs), differentiation studies, and potential therapeutic applications in regenerative medicine.

1.title: Design DNA oligos for Cpf1 crRNAs

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Design crRNA sequences encoding Cpf1 crRNAs using 23nt crRNA from the website https://portals.broadinstitute.org/gppx/crispick/public
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Design the DNA oligonucleotide by adding auxiliary bases to the crRNA guide sequence design
hierarchical_protocol.1.3: The addition of auxiliary bases generates annealed products with adhesive ends to facilitate cloning the annealed products to the Cpf1 crRNA backbone plasmids

2.title: Clone crRNA encoding oligos to AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-crRNA-cloning vector

hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Obtain the CAGGS-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-crRNA-cloning vector and the CMV:AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-crRNA-cloning vector from Addgene
hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Purify plasmids with the Omega Miniprep kit and measure concentration with a Nanodrop spectrometer
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Set up the restriction digestion reaction
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Incubate the enzymatic reaction at 37°C for 3 hours
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Purify the DNA from the enzymatic digestion using the Zymo DNA Clean & Concentrator
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Perform a 10× dilution of the annealed oligos
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Ligate the annealed oligo with BbsI-digested plasmid
hierarchical_protocol.2.5: Ligate at room temperature or 16°C overnight and transform Stbl3 chemically competent E. coli
hierarchical_protocol.2.6: Pick 3–6 individual colonies, inoculate 5mL of LB medium with 100 ug/mL ampicillin, and shake at 220 rpm at 30°C overnight
hierarchical_protocol.2.7: Make miniprep from the samples and sequence with U6 primer to determine clones with the correct crRNA sequence insertion
hierarchical_protocol.2.8: Make midi-prep of the correct plasmids using ZymoPURE II Plasmid Midiprep kit

3.title: Validation of crRNA by transfecting Cpf1 plasmids to HEK293T cells for genome editing

hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Culture HEK293T cells in DMEM high glucose medium supplemented with 10% FBS, 1×L-glutamine, 1× MEM-NEAA, and 1× penicillin/streptomycin
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Plate HEK293T cells in 12-well plates and transfect the cells with 0.5 ug of CMV-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-AAVS1-crRNA plasmid using Lipofectamine 2000 transfection reagent
hierarchical_protocol.3.3: Three days after transfection, dissociate cells with trypsin, followed by DNA purification with DNeasy Blood & Tissue Kit
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.2: Purify the PCR products using a PCR purification kit
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.3: Anneal a total of 200 ng PCR products in NEB buffer 2 and digest with 5 units of T7EI
hierarchical_protocol.3.5: Resolve DNA fragments with staining with ethidium bromide and take images with an AlphaImager gel documentation system

4.title: Knockin of the AAVS1 locus HEK293T cells by using the validated crRNA and a targeting construct

hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Obtain an AAVS1-tdT targeting plasmid from Addgene and purify following the previous procedures
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Transfect HEK293T cells with 0.8 ug of targeting vector AAVS1-CAGGStdTomato and 0.4 ug of AsCpf1-AAVS1 plasmid using Lipofectamine 2000 transfection reagent
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Sort GFP and tdTomato (tdT) double-positive cells 3 days post-transfection on a FACSAria
hierarchical_protocol.4.4: Mechanically passage individual tdT-expressing colonies to individual wells of a 12-well plate for expansion
hierarchical_protocol.4.5.1: Use 0.5 ug of genomic DNA for a PCR reaction with primer 495 and primer 489
hierarchical_protocol.4.5.2: Resolve PCR products with 1% agarose gels
hierarchical_protocol.4.5.3: Extract DNA from bands of the expected size with a gel purification kit and subject to Sanger sequencing with primer 495

5.title: Knockout of tdT in HEK293T-tdT cells by a tdT-crRNA

hierarchical_protocol.5.1: Design a tdT crRNA to target the 5' region of the tdT-coding sequence
hierarchical_protocol.5.2: Anneal the tdT-targeting crRNA oligos and ligate to CAGGS-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-crRNA-cloning vector
hierarchical_protocol.5.3: Transfect the CAGGS-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-tdT-crRNA plasmid to HEK293T-tdT cells
hierarchical_protocol.5.4: The cells with reduced tdT expression can be isolated with FACS sorting, followed by expansion and isolation of individual clones
hierarchical_protocol.5.5.2: Use it for PCR with the following primers: tdT-forward primer and tdT-reverse primer
hierarchical_protocol.5.5.3: Purify and sequence PCR amplicons with the tdT-forward primer to identify mutations in the tdT coding sequence

6.title: Genome editing of hPSCs by ablating expression of tdTomato

6.2.title: Generation of mouse embryonic fibroblast cells

hierarchical_protocol.6.2.1: Mating pairs of DR4 mice were set up, and timed pregnancies were determined by detection of vaginal plugs
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.2: At E13.5, pregnant DR4 female mice were euthanized by carbon dioxide (CO2) inhalation
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.3: Dissect the embryo and put it in PBS with penicillin/streptomycin in a biosafety cabinet
hierarchical_protocol.6.3: Remove the medium from confluent P2 MEF plates and add MEF medium with 5 ug/mL mitomycin C
hierarchical_protocol.6.4: Plate mitomycin C-inactivated MEF cells at a density of 0.4 million cells per well of a gelatin-coated 6-well plate
hierarchical_protocol.6.5.1: Electroporate the CAGGS-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-tdT-crRNA plasmid to H1-tdT cells
hierarchical_protocol.6.5.2: Culture hPSCs in the medium supplemented with 10 uM Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor Y-27632 overnight before dissociation and electroporation
hierarchical_protocol.6.6: Manually passage individual colonies onto MEF-coated 12-well plate wells
hierarchical_protocol.6.7.1: Use the primers tdT_Fwd and tdT_Rev to amplify the potentially edited regions of tdT with PCR
hierarchical_protocol.6.7.2: Sanger sequencing showed out-of-frame mutation in electroporated cells but not in control

7.title: Knockin of hPSC and multiplex genome editing

hierarchical_protocol.7.1: Maintain WIBR3 hPSCs in DMEM-F12 supplemented with 15% FBS, 5% KSR, 4 ng/mL FGF2, 1× 2-mercaptoethanol, 1× L-glutamine, 1× MEM-NEAA, and 1× penicillin/streptomycin

7.2.title: Electroporation of plasmids to WIBR3 hPSCs

hierarchical_protocol.7.2.1: One day before electroporation, culture cells in the medium supplemented with 10 uM Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor Y-27632
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.2: Dissociate approximately 10 million hPSCs into single cells with Accutase
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.3: Load the mixture to a 0.4 cm gap Gene Pulser electroporation cuvette and incubate on ice for 5 min before electroporation
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.1: Purify genomic DNA by isopropanol precipitation
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.2: Test the purified genomic DNA with PCR using the primers described in step D5
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.3: Perform Southern blots by digesting 15 ug of purified DNA with 50 units of SphI-HF
hierarchical_protocol.7.4.1: Perform immunofluorescence analyses of pluripotency markers in targeted WIBR3-tdT cells
hierarchical_protocol.7.4.2: Use the following antibodies: mouse anti-OCT3/4, rabbit anti-NANOG, mouse anti-TRA-1–60, and mouse anti-SSEA4 antibody
hierarchical_protocol.7.5.1: Targeting AAVS1 and MAFB are performed in the same way, except using the CAGGS-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-AAVS1-MAFB-crRNA
hierarchical_protocol.7.5.2: The correctly targeted clones are identified with PCR and sequencing validation of the correct junction sequences
hierarchical_protocol.7.6.1: Use the same reverse primer and differentially barcoded forward primers
hierarchical_protocol.7.6.2: Set up PCR reactions based on the conditions described in step C4 and 30s of amplification time
hierarchical_protocol.8.1: Plate a total of 5 million dissociated WIBR3 or WIBR3-tdT cells to one Matrigel-coated 6-well plate well in NGD medium
hierarchical_protocol.8.2: Passage NP cells every 3 days in NGD medium with 10 ng/mL FGF2, 1:500 insulin
hierarchical_protocol.8.3: For neuronal differentiation, plate about 0.2 million NP cells in each 12-well plate well in 1 mL of NGD medium
hierarchical_protocol.8.4: Fix NP and neurons after 4–6 weeks of differentiation using the immunofluorescence protocols
hierarchical_protocol.9.1: The INS crRNA was designed, generated, and validated in a similar way as described before
hierarchical_protocol.9.2: Electroporation was performed as described before
hierarchical_protocol.9.3: The generated CAGGS-AsCpf1-2A-GFP-U6-INS-crRNA plasmid is available from Addgene
hierarchical_protocol.9.4.1: Amplify the internal probe with PCR with the following primers and firefly luciferase gene as a template
hierarchical_protocol.9.4.2: Amplify the external probe with PCR with the following primers and genomic DNA from H1-OCT4-GFP hPSCs
hierarchical_protocol.10.1: Adapt H1-OCT4-GFP-INS-tdT hPSC cells for feeder-free conditions by culturing in Matrigel-coated tissue culture plates in mTeSR
hierarchical_protocol.10.2: Treat PSCs with mTeSR medium supplemented with 10 uM Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor Y-27632 overnight
hierarchical_protocol.10.3.1: S1 (3 days) base medium: MCDB131 with 0.5% FAF-BSA, 1.5 g/L NaHCO3, 10 mM glucose, 1× GlutaMAX, 1× penicillin/streptomycin
hierarchical_protocol.10.3.2: S2 (2 days) base medium: MCDB131 with 0.5% FAF-BSA, 1.5 g/L NaHCO3, 10 mM glucose, 1× penicillin/streptomycin, 1× GlutaMAX, and 0.25 mM Vc
hierarchical_protocol.10.3.3: S3 (2 days) base medium: MCDB131 with 2% FAF-BSA, 1.5 g/L NaHCO3, 10 mM glucose, 1× penicillin/streptomycin, 1× GlutaMAX, 0.25 mM Vc, and 0.5× insulin-transferrin-selenium-ethanolamine
hierarchical_protocol.10.4.1: Add 15 mg/mL D-luciferin to undifferentiated hPSC or INS reporter cells differentiated to β-cells
hierarchical_protocol.10.4.2: Acquire luciferase signals with an IVIS Spectrum imager
hierarchical_protocol.11.1: The predicted off-target sites can be obtained from http://www.rgenome.net/cas-offinder
hierarchical_protocol.11.2.2: Resolve PCR products with 1% agarose gel followed by purification with a gel purification kit
hierarchical_protocol.11.2.3: Sanger sequencing with the sequencing primers listed in Table 5

title: Assessment and Quantification of Foam Cells and Lipid Droplet– Accumulating Microglia in Mouse Brain Tissue Using BODIPY Staining
abstract: This paper presents a refined, user-friendly protocol for using boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) to assess and quantify foam cells and lipid droplet–accumulating microglia (LDAM) in mouse brain tissue. The protocol aims to enhance existing methodologies by offering precise and efficient evaluation of foam cells and LDAM burden in various neuropathological conditions linked to lipid metabolism and neuroinflammation. A notable challenge in analyzing tissue from mouse models of these neurodegenerative disorders is the interference caused by the autofluorescent molecule lipofuscin. Our protocol addresses this issue with specific steps that effectively distinguish BODIPY fluorescence from lipofuscin autofluorescence, using advanced imaging techniques and filter settings to ensure accurate and reliable analysis. By providing a straightforward and accessible method, this research aims to facilitate the broader adoption of BODIPY-based techniques for detailed foam cell and LDAM analysis in mouse brain tissue, potentially enhancing diagnostic capabilities and deepening our understanding of how these cells contribute to neurodegenerative disease mechanisms.
problem: The challenge of accurately assessing and quantifying foam cells and lipid droplet–accumulating microglia (LDAM) in mouse brain tissue due to interference from autofluorescent lipofuscin, which complicates analysis in neuropathological conditions.
method: Using boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) staining combined with advanced imaging techniques and specific filter settings to distinguish BODIPY fluorescence from lipofuscin autofluorescence.
innovation: Improved specificity and accuracy in quantifying foam cells and LDAM by effectively mitigating lipofuscin interference, offering a user-friendly and accessible protocol.
application: Analysis of neuropathological conditions related to lipid metabolism and neuroinflammation in mouse brain tissue, enhancing diagnostic capabilities and research into neurodegenerative disease mechanisms.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Select infarcted mouse brain tissue sections.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Note: If only staining for BODIPY, skip to step 8.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Place tissue in a 12-well tissue culture plate and wash three times for 10 min each in 0.1M PBS at room temperature (RT) on a shaker.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Block for 1h at RT with 10% goat serum and 0.3% Triton X-100 in 0.1 M PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Tip: Make sure the blocking solution uses serum from the species in which the secondary antibody was generated.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Incubate overnight at room temperature on a rotator in 3% goat serum and 0.3% Triton X100 in 0.1M PBS containing: 1:500 anti-CD68 made in rat and 1:500 anti-Iba1 made in rabbit.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Tip: If the staining is faint, increase the antibody concentration. If there is excessive background, reduce the antibody concentration. The recommended dilution is 1:500–1,000. Another alternative when staining is too faint is to increase the incubation time to 48–72h.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1: Wash three times for 10min each in 0.1M PBS at RT on a shaker.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1: Incubate for 2~h at RT in 3% goat serum +~0.3% Triton X-100 in 0.1 M PBS with 1:500 goat anti-rabbit and 1:500 goat anti-rat.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2: Tip: If the staining is faint, increase the antibody concentration. If there is excessive background, reduce the antibody concentration. The recommended dilution is 1:500–1,000. Another alternative is to increase the incubation time to 4h.
hierarchical_protocol.6.3: Note: From this point onward, keep samples protected from light.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1: Wash three times for 10min each in 0.1 M PBS at RT on a shaker.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1: Gently place tissue sections in 0.1~M~ PBS and mount them on slides.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2: Notes: a. Air dry slides for approximately 30 min. b. To avoid drying the tissue, do not leave the slides out for more than 1 h.
hierarchical_protocol.9.1: Draw a hydrophobic barrier around the sections with the hydrophobic pen.
hierarchical_protocol.10.1: Wash the sections three times for 10min each in 0.1~M~ PBS at RT.
hierarchical_protocol.11.1: Incubate the sections in a solution of 1:25 BODIPY 492/515 in DMSO for 30 min, protected from light.
hierarchical_protocol.12.1: Wash the sections three times for 10min each in 0.1 M PBS at RT, protected from light.
hierarchical_protocol.13.1: Mount the sections with antifade mounting media.
hierarchical_protocol.13.2: Incubate for 1-2h at RT, protected from light.
hierarchical_protocol.14.1: Detect the fluorescence emission of BODIPY 493/503-stained samples using a fluorescence microscope equipped with a 493~nm excitation filter and a 503~nm emission filter.

title: Accurate Measurement of Cell Number– Normalized Differential Gene Expression in Cells Treated With Retinoic Acid
abstract: Genome-wide gene expression analysis is a commonly used method to quantitatively examine the transcriptional signature of any tissue or cell state. Standard bulk cell RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) quantifies RNAs in the cells of the tissue type of interest through massive parallel sequencing of cDNA synthesized from the cellular RNA. The subsequent analysis of global RNA expression and normalization of RNA expression levels between two or more samples generally assumes that cells from all samples produce equivalent amounts of RNA per cell. This assumption may be invalid in cells where MYC or MYCN expression levels are markedly different and thus, overall mRNA expression per cell is altered. Here, we describe an approach for RNA-seq analysis of MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma cells during treatment with retinoic acid, which causes dramatic downregulation of MYCN expression and induces growth arrest and differentiation of the cells. Our procedure employs spiked-in RNA standards added in ratio to the number of cells in each sample prior to RNA extraction. In the analysis of differential gene expression, the expression level of each gene is standardized to the spiked-in RNA standard to accurately assess gene expression levels per cell in conditions of high and low MYCN expression. Our protocol thus provides a stepby-step experimental approach for normalizing RNA-seq expression data on a per-cell-number basis, allowing accurate assessment of differential gene expression in cells expressing markedly different levels of MYC or MYCN.
problem: Standard RNA-seq normalization assumes equal RNA output per cell, which is invalid in cells with varying MYC or MYCN expression levels, leading to inaccurate differential gene expression analysis.
method: RNA-seq analysis using spiked-in RNA standards added in proportion to cell number, enabling normalization of gene expression on a per-cell basis during retinoic acid treatment.
innovation: Use of spiked-in RNA standards to account for differing RNA output per cell, providing accurate per-cell gene expression normalization in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma cells undergoing differentiation and growth arrest.
application: Primarily designed for MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma cells treated with retinoic acid, adaptable to other cell types with variable MYC or MYCN expression levels, ensuring precise differential gene expression analysis.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Seed 0.1×10^6 BE2C cells in 6-well plates in enough wells for each replicate plus at least one additional sample for RNA extraction test run.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Start treatment of BE2C cells with either 5uL of DMSO as control or 5uM ATRA.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Change 3mL of RPMI with DMSO or 5uM ATRA every 3 days.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Grow BE2C cells under the required experimental conditions for six days.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Aspirate the RPMI, wash 1× with 3mL of PBS, and add 1~mL of trypsin to each well.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Collect each well into a separate 15mL collection tube and spin the cells down at 800×g for 5 min.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.3: Discard the supernatant and wash the cells one time with 5mL of PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.4: Resuspend cells in 1~mL of PBS into a 1.5mL tube each.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.5: Combine 20uL of the resuspended cells with 20uL of 0.4% trypan blue and mix well.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.6: Pipette 10~uL of this mix into a Countess chamber slide and insert the slide into the Countess 3 automated cell counter.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.7: Document the viable cell count per milliliter for each sample and calculate the absolute viable cell count.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.1: Pellet the cells, remove the supernatant, and snap freeze in dry ice with ethanol.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Store samples at -80°C until ready to proceed.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Begin with only the extra fourth sample collected for each experimental group.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Resuspend the frozen cell pellets in 1~mL of TRIzol reagent and incubate at room temperature for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Add 0.2mL of chloroform using a glass pipette, mix for 15s, and incubate for 2min at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Centrifuge the samples at 12,000×g for 10min at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: Transfer the aqueous phase to new tubes and precipitate the RNA from the aqueous phase by adding 0.5mL of isopropanol.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4: Incubate samples at room temperature for 10min and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 10min at 4°C.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.5: Remove the supernatant, wash the RNA pellet once with 1.0mL of 75% ethanol, and mix by pipetting up and down.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Dissolve the RNA pellet in 100~uL of RNase-free water, add 350~uL of lysis buffer RLT, and mix by pipetting up and down.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Add 250~uL of ethanol to the diluted RNA and mix by pipetting up and down.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Apply the sample to an RNeasy extraction column placed in a 2~mL collection tube and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 1 min at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.4: Prepare DNase by adding 10uL of DNase to 70uL of RDD buffer and keeping it on ice.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.5: Add 350~uL of wash buffer 1 RW1, spin at 12,000×g for 15s at room temperature, and discard the flowthrough.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.6: Add 80uL of DNase mix to the column and incubate at room temperature for 15min.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.7: Add 350~uL of wash buffer 1 RW1 to each column, spin the column at 12,000×g for 15s at room temperature, and discard the flowthrough.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.8: Add 500~uL of wash buffer 2 RPE onto the column and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 15 s at room temperature to wash the column.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.9: Add another 500~uL of wash buffer 2 RPE to the RNeasy column and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 2min at room temperature.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.10: Transfer the column to a new 1.5~mL collection tube, add 30~uL RNase-free water, and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 1 min at room temperature to elute total RNA.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Quantify and record the total amount of RNA in each sample using Nanodrop.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Calculate the volume of ERCC spike-in mix 1 to add to each sample based on the sample with the highest amount of extracted RNA.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Serial dilute the ERCC spike-in mix 1 according to Table 1.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.3: Determine the volume of diluted ERCC spike-in mix 1 to add to the sample with the highest amount of extracted RNA according to Table 2.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Resuspend the experimental frozen cell pellets in 1mL of TRIzol reagent and incubate at room temperature for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Add the calculated volume of appropriately diluted ERCC spike-in mix 1 to each sample by adding it directly to the cells resuspended in TRIzol solution.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.3: Extract and quantify RNA from each sample by repeating steps B2–18.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: Prepare samples using commercially available library preparation kits, typically starting with 500ng of purified total RNA according to the manufacturer’s protocol.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Quantify the finished dsDNA libraries by Qubit fluorometer, TapeStation 4200, and RT-qPCR using the Kapa Biosystems library quantification kit for quality control.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Pool indexed libraries in equimolar ratios and pair-end sequence on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 sequencer with the NovaSeq 6000 Reagent Kit v1.5, with 100 cycles at 0.7nM loading concentration.

title: PEPITA: Parallelized High-Throughput Quantification  of  Ototoxicity and Otoprotection in Zebrafish Larvae
abstract: Drug-induced hearing injury (ototoxicity) is a common, debilitating side effect of many antibiotic regimens that can be worsened by adverse drug interactions. Such adverse drug interactions are often not detected until after drugs are already on the market because of the difficulty of measuring all possible drug combinations. While in vivo mammalian assays to screen for ototoxic damage exist, they are currently time-consuming, costly, and limited in throughput, which limits their utility in assessing drug interaction outcomes. To facilitate more rapid quantification of ototoxicity and assessment of adverse drug interactions that impact ototoxicity, we have developed a highthroughput workflow we call parallelized evaluation of protection and injury for toxicity assessment (PEPITA). PEPITA uses zebrafish larvae to quantify ototoxic damage and protection. Previous work has shown that hair cells (HCs) in the zebrafish lateral line are very similar to human inner ear HCs, meaning zebrafish are a viable model to test drug-induced ototoxicity. In PEPITA, we expose zebrafish larvae to different combinations of drugs, fluorescently label the HCs, and subsequently use microscopy to quantify the brightness of the fluorescently labeled HCs as an assay for ototoxic damage and hair-cell viability. PEPITA is a reproducible, low-cost, technically accessible, and high-throughput assay. These advantages allow many experiments to be conducted in parallel, paving the way for systematic evaluation of drug-induced hearing injury and other multidrug interactions.
problem: Current mammalian assays for detecting drug-induced hearing injury (ototoxicity) are time-consuming, costly, and limited in throughput, hindering the assessment of adverse drug interactions.
method: Use of zebrafish larvae exposed to drug combinations, fluorescent labeling of hair cells (HCs) in the lateral line, and microscopy-based quantification of HC fluorescence brightness to assess ototoxicity and hair-cell viability.
innovation: High-throughput, parallelized workflow (PEPITA) that is reproducible, low-cost, and technically accessible, enabling systematic evaluation of ototoxicity and multidrug interactions.
application: Screening for ototoxicity and otoprotection in drug development, assessing adverse drug interactions, and facilitating research on hearing injury in a zebrafish model that mimics human inner ear hair cells.

# Biological materials

2.  Tg (𝑚𝑦𝑜6𝑏: 𝐸𝐺𝐹𝑃)𝑤119𝑇𝑔; myo6b::gfp zebrafish 8

# Reagents

Note: Azithromycin and neomycin are listed as examples of antibiotics used, but any drugs of interest can be used here.

2. Neomycin sulfate hydrate (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: AAJ6149914)
3. Texas red-X succinimidyl ester (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: T20175) (store at -20^°C_ )

# Solutions
