5. Tricaine: anesthesia solution (0.675mM) (see Recipes)
6.  ICS water (see Recipes)

# Recipes

# 1.  Neomycin super-concentrated stock solution

Note: This is an example of an antibiotic solution. The super-concentrated stock solution concentrations and solvents used will vary between drugs. Store at -20~^°C or -80^°C. .

()

# 2.  YO-PRO-1 solution (2uM)

Note: The recipe is for one 12-well plate, using 3,500 μL of YO-PRO-1 solution per well. Adjust volumes as needed, depending on the size of the multi-well plate being used. Store at -20^°C. .

()

3.  Tricaine: stock solution (15 mM)

()
Store at -20 °C.

4.  Tricaine: euthanasia solution (1.35mM)

()

# 5.  Tricaine: anesthesia solution (0.675mM)

Note: The recipe is for one 12-well plate, using 3,500 μL of tricaine solution per well. Adjust volumes as needed, depending on the size of the multi-well plate being used.

()

Cite as: Nilles, E. M. et al. (2024). PEPITA: Parallelized High-Throughput Quantification of Ototoxicity and Otoprotection in Zebrafish Larvae. Bio-protocol 14(21): e5105. DOI: 10.21769/BioProtoc.5105.

()

# 6. ICS water

Note: Any type of “fish water” or embryo medium safe for use with zebrafish embryos and larvae can be used in place of ICS water. However, bear in mind that differing water composition may cause hair cell sensitivity to damage to vary.

()

# Laboratory supplies

Note: Supplies indicated with an asterisk are brand-specific because the Tinkercad design for the multi-well platestrainer inserts may not fit multi-well plates from other manufacturers.

1.  Breeding tanks with dividers (Carolina Biological Supply, catalog number: 161937)
2. 12-well plates, non-treated* (Corning Costar, catalog number: 07-201-589)
3. 24-well plates, non-treated* (Corning Costar, catalog number: 07-201-590)
4. 96-well plates, non-treated, black, flat-bottom, for imaging (Thermo Fisher, catalog number: 37000-550)
5. 3D printer filament, PLA (Amazon, catalog number: B084XS2TS9)
6. Nylon mesh, 125 micron (ELKO Filtering Co., catalog number: 03-125/39)
7. Wide-bore Pasteur pipettes* (Fisherbrand, catalog number: 13-678-30)
Note: Wide-bore Pasteur pipettes are necessary because the embryos will not fit into standard Pasteur pipets.
8. 100um cell strainers (Corning, catalog number: 07-201-432)
9.  Petri dishes 100:mm×15:mm) ) (Falcon, catalog number: 08-757-100D)
10. Large Petri dishes ( .150:mm×:15:mm) ) (VWR, catalog number: 25384-326)
11. Compressed air duster cleaner (Inovera, catalog number: IVR10012)
12. Fine-tipped tweezers (Dumont Tweezer, Style 5, catalog number: 0203-5-PO)

# Equipment

1. All-in-one fluorescence microscope (Keyence, model: BZ-X710)
2. 3D printer (Dremel, model: Digilab 3D45 3-D printer)
3.  Hot plate (Fisher Scientific, Thermix Stirring Hot Plate, model: 210T)
4. Vortex mixer (VWR, catalog number: 10153-838)
5.  Digital dry bath (BioRad, catalog number: 1160562)

# Software and datasets

1. Tinkercad design for multi-well plate-strainer inserts (freely available at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5676024)
2. PEPITA-tools software package can be found on GitHub at https://github.com/ma-lab-cgidr/PEPITA-tools
3. ImageJ (version 1.54f, 06/29/2023)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: 3D-print the Tinkercad design for the appropriately sized multi-well plate strainer insert.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Set a hot plate to medium heat and let it heat up.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Cut rectangles of nylon mesh, approximately 9cm×12cm.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Fold a piece of aluminum foil over itself so that it forms a double-layer piece of foil that is slightly bigger than the nylon mesh pieces.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.1: Once at temperature, place the double layer of aluminum foil on the hot plate.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Place a rectangle of nylon mesh on top of the aluminum foil.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.3: Immediately press the 3D-printed multi-well insert into the nylon mesh, applying enough pressure for the bottom of the insert to melt onto the nylon mesh.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.4: Apply pressure for 3 s, then quickly press around the edge of each well to form a complete seal between the bottom of the 3D-printed insert and the nylon mesh.
hierarchical_protocol.1.5.1: Once off the hot plate, immediately press the insert into the nylon mesh for 3 more seconds on the benchtop to further adhere the 3D-printed insert to the nylon mesh.
hierarchical_protocol.1.5.2: Gently peel off the foil from the insert.
hierarchical_protocol.1.5.3: Check to ensure the bottom of each well of the insert forms a complete seal with the nylon mesh.
hierarchical_protocol.1.5.4: If necessary, repeat steps A6–8 several more times until this is achieved.
hierarchical_protocol.1.6.1: Use small scissors to cut away the excess nylon mesh remaining between wells.
hierarchical_protocol.1.6.2: Feel around the bottom of each well to ensure that the seal with the mesh has not been compromised during the trimming process.
hierarchical_protocol.1.7.1: Prepare a container of 10% bleach solution and completely submerge the completed multi-well inserts in the bleach solution for at least 20min and no longer than 24h.
hierarchical_protocol.1.7.2: Prepare a container of distilled water and transfer the multi-well inserts from the bleach solution to the distilled water and let soak for up to 24h.
hierarchical_protocol.1.7.3: After soaking, remove the multi-well inserts from the distilled water and let air dry. Store in a clean plastic bag until ready to use.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Select healthy zebrafish from a stock population and place into breeding tanks—females on one side of each tank and males on the other.

2.2.title: Day 0: Water Change, Execute Crossing, Collect Embryos

hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: When the tank room lights turn on, promptly refresh the water in the breeding tanks, remove the breeding dividers, and execute crossing.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Observe fish until they start spawning, and clear, viable embryos are produced.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3.1: Prepare a bleach solution in a beaker: 100uL of bleach, 150mL of ICS water.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3.2: Recover all embryos from the tank by straining out embryos with a strainer.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3.3: Rinse embryos into bleach solution using an ICS water squirt bottle.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3.4: Leave embryos in the bleach solution for 10min. Swirl eggs intermittently.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4.1: Strain the embryos in the bleach solution by pouring the bleach solution with embryos back through the strainer into the sink.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4.2: Rinse embryos in the strainer thoroughly with ICS water.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.4.3: Partition embryos into Petri dishes. Aim for 100 embryos per Petri dish.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Under a dissecting microscope, find all viable embryos and transfer them with a wide-bore Pasteur pipette into new Petri dishes with new ICS water.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Aim for 50 (no more than 60) embryos per Petri dish.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.3: Place Petri dishes in an incubator overnight at 28.5°C.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: For larvae that have not yet emerged, remove their chorions using fine-tipped tweezers.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Place remaining larvae (in Petri dishes) in an incubator overnight at 28.5°C.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Prepare appropriate working concentrations of the drugs of interest.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Transfer appropriate drug treatments into their respective wells in a multi-well plate.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Pour larvae into a cell strainer and place in a Petri dish with ICS water.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Place the appropriate multi-well plate-strainer insert in a large Petri dish full of water.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.3: Transfer the appropriate number of larvae from the cell strainer into each well of the insert.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.1: Incubate the larvae in the drug treatment for the desired drug exposure time.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.2: While larvae are in drug treatment, warm the ICS water to 28°C in an incubator and thaw the Tricaine stock.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.1: One hour before the larvae come out of drug treatment, turn off lights and thaw YO-PRO-1 solution.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.2: Prepare YO-PRO-1 solution in a glass bottle or 50mL tube covered in foil.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.3: Transfer YO-PRO-1 solution into each well of a new multi-well plate, cover with foil, and place in a 28°C incubator until the end of drug treatment.
hierarchical_protocol.3.6.1: Fill a tub with about 1 cm of fresh ICS water for washing.
hierarchical_protocol.3.6.2: After the desired length of drug treatment, promptly remove the drug treatment plate from the incubator.
hierarchical_protocol.3.6.3: Dunk each multi-well strainer insert into the same ICS washing tub three times to wash off residual drug treatment.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.1: Transfer the multi-well strainer inserts into the plate with YO-PRO-1 solution.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.2: Cover with foil and incubate for 20min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.3: After 20min, remove the insert from the YO-PRO-1 solution and dunk it into the ICS washing tub 3× to wash off residual YO-PRO-1 stain.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.4: Transfer to the plate with Tricaine: anesthesia solution.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.5: Wait about 5 min or until the larvae stop moving.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.6: Transfer larvae one by one to an untreated 96-well imaging plate using a P200 with a cut tip set at 75uL.
hierarchical_protocol.3.7.7: Image larvae using a fluorescence microscope with a robotics-assisted stage.
hierarchical_protocol.3.8.1: After imaging, transfer extra larvae into empty wells of the imaging plate.
hierarchical_protocol.3.8.2: Add about 200uL of Tricaine euthanasia solution to each fish-containing well to euthanize.
hierarchical_protocol.3.8.3: After at least 10 min in Tricaine: euthanasia solution, put the plates in a -20°C freezer for secondary euthanasia.

title: The on-Site Monitoring and SpecimenMaking of Ectoparasites on Rodents and Other Small Mammals
abstract: The ectoparasites of rodents and other small mammals usually involve five categories of arthropods—fleas, sucking lice, gamasid mites, chigger mites, and occasionally, ticks. These ectoparasites are medically important, serving as vectors for diseases such as plague, murine typhus, scrub typhus, forest encephalitis, Lyme disease, and other zoonoses. Field surveys, collection, and specimen preparation of ectoparasites are crucial for studying taxonomy, faunistics, ecology, and epidemiology. They are also essential for vector surveillance. The present protocol summarizes the on-site monitoring and specimen-making of ectoparasites of rodents and other sympatric small mammals. Besides the collection and specimen preparation of small mammal hosts, the protocol describes in detail the collection, fixation, specimen-making, and taxonomic identification of ectoparasites and provides some monitoring indices. The on-site monitoring indices include the host density index and the infestation indices of ectoparasites (prevalence, mean abundance, mean intensity). The methodologies outlined in this protocol provide technical guidance and references for vector monitoring (surveillance) and control.
problem: Challenges in efficient field monitoring, collection, and specimen preparation of ectoparasites on rodents and small mammals, critical for studying disease vectors and zoonoses.
method: On-site monitoring involving the collection of small mammal hosts, ectoparasite collection, fixation, and specimen-making, followed by taxonomic identification and calculation of monitoring indices such as host density and infestation indices.
innovation: Comprehensive approach integrating field collection, specimen preparation, and quantitative indices (prevalence, mean abundance, mean intensity) for ectoparasite monitoring, ensuring standardized documentation and taxonomic accuracy.
application: Essential for vector surveillance, epidemiology, and ecological studies of ectoparasites on rodents and small mammals, aiding in the control of zoonotic diseases such as plague, murine typhus, and Lyme disease.
input:
# Reagents

1. Cresol solution (Shanghai Hengyuan Biochemical Reagent, catalog number: 7784-24-9)
2. Potassium aluminum sulfate (Shanghai Hengyuan Biochemical Reagent, catalog number: 7784-24-9)
3. Arsenic trioxide (Yunnan Tin Co, catalog number: 1327-53-3)
4. Camphor powder (Shanghai Anpu Experimental Technology, catalog number: 464-49-3)
5. Xylene (Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, catalog number: 1330-20-7)
6. Distilled water
7. Canadian balsam (Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology, catalog number: 8007-47-4), neutral balsam (Shanghai  Macklin  Biochemical  Technology,  catalog  number:  96949-21-2),  or  fir  balsam  (Aibixin Biotechnology, catalog number: 8016-42-0)
8.  Pomegranate oil (Xi’an Rongbai Biological Technology, catalog number: 84961-57-9) or clove oil (Jiangxi Baicao Pharmaceutical, catalog number: 8000-34-8)
9.  Arabic gum (Shanghai Yiji Industrial, catalog number: 9000-01-5)
10. Formaldehyde (Beijing Qinling Pharmaceutical Technology, catalog number: 79083-29-7)
11. Glycerin (Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, catalog number 56-81-5)
12. 10% sodium hydroxide (Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology, catalog number 1310-73-2) or potassium hydroxide (Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, catalog number 1310-58-3) solution

# Solutions

1. 5%-10% cresol soap solution (Lysol) (see Recipes)
2. Alum arsenic preservative (see Recipes)
3. Hoyer’s solution or Berlese’s solution (see Recipes)
4. Different concentrations of ethanol ( 30% , 50% , 70% , 80% , 90% , 95% and 100% anhydrous ethanol) The different concentrations of ethanol can be prepared by diluting anhydrous ethanol with distilled water. Anhydrous ethanol is a kind of very commonly used reagent with a wide choice of catalog numbers and manufacturers. We use anhydrous ethanol from Wuhan Jisi Instruments & Equipment (catalog number: 64-17- 5).

# Recipes

# 1. 5%-10% cresol soap solution (Lysol)

5mL of cresol solution +95mL of distilled water for making 5% cresol soap solution.
10mL of cresol solution +90mL of distilled water for making 10% cresol soap solution.
In a beaker, mix the cresol and water and shake or stir until the cresol is completely dissolved in the water.

# 2.  Alum arsenic preservative

Potassium aluminum sulfate (powder, accounting for 40% or 70% ) ^+ arsenic trioxide (powder, 20% ) ^+ camphor powder 40% or 10% ). Mix them together.

# 3.  Hoyer’s solution or Berlese’s solution

a.  Hoyer’s solution (or Hoyer’s medium) 50mL of distilled water, 30g of Arabic gum, 200g of formaldehyde, 20mL of glycerin.
b.  Berlese’s solution (or Berlese medium) 20mL of distilled water, 15~g~ of Arabic gum, 160 g of formaldehyde, 20mL of glycerin.

# Laboratory supplies

# A. Collection and specimen preparation of small mammal hosts

1.  Fieldwork equipment (field tent, backpack, raincoat, non-slip shoes, flashlight)
2. Disinfection and protection materials: 70% or 75% ethanol (Wuhan Jisi Instruments & Equipment, catalog number: 64-17-5), protective clothing and hat, medical latex gloves, mask
3. Trapping materials a.  Rat cage 18cm×12cm×9cm, Jiangxi Guixi Li’s Rat Trap Equipment Co., Ltd.) b.  Food bait (peanuts, corn, cooked meat, fried dough sticks, steamed buns) c.  Disposable white cloth bag
4. Recording materials (pen, marker, pencil, collection information record book)
5. Specimen preparation materials for small mammals lancet, surgical scissors, tweezers, steel ruler or tape measure, electronic scale, degreased cotton, bamboo sticks, wooden sticks, suture needles, specimen labels, beakers, alcohol lamps (for boiling small animal skulls), ether, alum arsenic preservative a.  Host tissue sample collection and preservation materials: Cryopreservation tubes and 95%-100% alcohol

# B.  Collection and fixation of ectoparasites

1. White square plate (large size: 565:mm×400:mm , small size: 385:mm×285:mm) )
2. Lidded centrifuge tubes
3. Ophthalmic forceps
4. 70% or 75% ethanol
5. Marking pens

# C. Specimen-making of flea and sucking lice

1. Glass slides
2. Coverslips
3. Baking plate or baking rack
4. Specimen box
5. Marker pen
6. Label paper

Cite as: Yin, P. W. et al. (2024). The on-Site Monitoring and Specimen-Making of Ectoparasites on Rodents and Other Small Mammals. Bio-protocol 14(21): e5104. DOI: 10.21769/BioProtoc.5104.

# D. Specimen-making of gamasid mites and chigger mites

1. Petri dish
2. Brush
3. Slide
4. Coverslip
5. Marker pen
6. Label paper

E. Specimen-making of ticks

1. Wide-mouth bottle
2. Cover glass
3. Sealing wax

# Equipment

1. Stereomicroscope (Leica, model: DM3000)
2. Baking oven (Shanghai Yiheng Scientific Instrument, model: DHG-9420A)

1.title: Collection and Specimen Preparation of Small Mammal Hosts

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Select the survey site and set rat cages: Prior to placing the rat cage, you should observe signs such as food residues, feces, rat trails, and rat holes.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Choose food baits: This can be flexible according to the specific situation.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.3: Place rat cages (trap cages) with baits in the afternoon or evening of the survey day to trap rodents and other sympatric small mammals (hosts) in various geographical and ecological environments.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.4: In monitoring the density of small mammal hosts, quantitative placement of rat cages is required.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.5: The number of cages placed at each survey point should be as uniform as possible to ensure the homogeneity and comparability of the samples from each survey point.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: After being placed for three consecutive days, relocate to a new location and repeat the process.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Collect the captured small mammal hosts: The following morning, collect the captured rodents and other sympatric small mammal hosts and place them, along with the rat cage, into a white cloth rat bag.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Transport the bag to a temporary on-site laboratory for ectoparasite collection.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Prior to reuse, the rat bag must be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected to prevent cross-contamination of ectoparasites between different host mammals.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.3: Collect ectoparasites: Rodent hosts considered pests can be euthanized by cervical dislocation or anesthesia.

1.4.title: Tissue Specimen Collection and Record Keeping

hierarchical_protocol.1.4.1: After ectoparasite collection, collect tissue specimens (muscle, bone, or internal organ specimens) from the host mammals, if needed.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Record the relevant information of the collected host mammals according to Tables 1 and 2.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Euthanize small mammals via cervical dislocation or anesthesia.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Uniformly paint an alum arsenic preservative to the inner surface of the rodent skin.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: If a posture specimen is required, first construct a dummy frame using wires, comparable in size and shape to the rodent body.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Sew the rodent skin using a needle and thread and adjust its shape and posture through a process termed'shaping'.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Upon successful creation of the taxidermy specimen, affix the posture specimen to an appropriate platform for ease of display.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Accompany each specimen with a label (either label paper or a label card) with information such as the scientific name of the rodent.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.1: Place the entire skull of the rodent (rat, mouse, or vole), detached from the stuffed specimen, in a container filled with water and boil it.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1.2: Once nearly cooked, remove the skull and eliminate all soft tissues such as muscles and fascia.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.1: Once all soft tissues are removed and the skull is naturally dried, it becomes the host skull specimen.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2.2: Store the skull specimens in a dry, well-ventilated area.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.1: To prevent ectoparasites from attacking and biting the operator, anesthetize both the host mammals and the ectoparasites with ether prior to the collection of ectoparasites.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1.2: Use a toothbrush or comb to brush the host mammals from head to tail 2–3 times, aiming to brush the majority of the ectoparasites into the small plate.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.1: Adhering to the principle of 'one host, one vial', place all collected ectoparasites into a container filled with 70% or 75% ethanol for fixation and preservation.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2.2: Use an oil-based marker to label the container used for fixation and preservation.

5.title: Specimen-Making of Fleas and Sucking Lice

hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Transfer the fleas and sucking lice, which are preserved in 70% or 75% ethanol, into a culture dish filled with clean or distilled water.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Move the thoroughly washed flea and sucking lice into a solution of 5% or 10% potassium hydroxide or sodium hydroxide.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Transfer the digested flea and sucking louse specimens into clean or distilled water and wash them 2–3 times for 30min each.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Place 2–3 drops of lipid-soluble adhesives such as Canada balsam, neutral balsam, or fir balsam on the center of a clean glass slide.

6.title: Specimen-Making of Gamasid Mites and Chigger Mites

hierarchical_protocol.6.1.1: Transfer the gamasid mites and chiggers, which have been fixed and preserved in 70% or 75% ethanol, into a Petri dish containing clean or distilled water.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1.2: Place 2–3 drops of mounting fluid (Hoyer’s solution or Berlese’s solution) on the center of a clean slide.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.1: Lay the mounted slide specimens flat on a specialized baking plate or rack and bake in an oven at 45–60 ^°C for 7–15 days or longer until the mounting fluid has dried.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2.2: Once dried and transparent, the specimens can be clearly observed under a microscope for morphological structure examination and taxonomic identification.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.1: For larger ticks, field-collected specimens can be transferred to a wide-mouth bottle containing 70% or 75% ethanol for long-term preservation.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1.2: Seal the bottle cap with sealing wax.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2.1: Refer to the method outlined in Section C for preparing slide specimens of smaller ticks, including larvae and nymphs of certain species.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.1: Once the collection, fixation, preservation, and specimen-making of ectoparasites are completed, identify each type of ectoparasites as soon as possible.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1.2: Prepare the necessary identification tools, books, and literature related to taxonomic identification, including taxonomic keys.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.1: Using the taxonomic tools, books, literature, and taxonomic keys, carefully observe, measure, and compare the relevant morphological structures and characteristics.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2.2: Each ectoparasite specimen should be gradually identified according to the taxonomic levels of order, family, genus, and species.

title: Fluorescent Staining and Quantification of Starch Granules in Chloroplasts of Live Plant Cells Using Fluorescein
abstract: Plants use C O_2 , water, and light energy to generate carbohydrates through photosynthesis. During daytime, these carbohydrates are polymerized, leading to the accumulation of starch granules in chloroplasts. The catabolites produced by the degradation of these chloroplast starch granules are used for physiological responses and plant growth. Various staining methods, such as iodine staining, have previously been used to visualize the accumulation of chloroplast starch granules; however, these staining methods cannot be used to image live cells and/or provide confocal images with non-specific signals. In this study, we developed a new imaging method for the fluorescent observation of chloroplast starch granules in living plant cells by staining with fluorescein, a widely available fluorescent dye. This simple staining method, which involves soaking a leaf disk in staining solution, shows high specificity in confocal images. Fluorescent images of the stained tissue allow the cellular starch content of living cells to be quantified with the same level of accuracy as a conventional biochemical method (amyloglucosidase/α- amylase method). Fluorescein staining thus not only enables the easy and clear observation of chloroplast starch granules but also allows for precise quantification in living cells.
problem: Existing staining methods, such as iodine staining, cannot image chloroplast starch granules in live plant cells or provide high-specificity confocal images, limiting real-time observation and quantification of starch accumulation.
method: Fluorescent staining of chloroplast starch granules using fluorescein, followed by confocal imaging and quantification of starch content in live plant cells.
innovation: Fluorescein staining enables live-cell imaging with high specificity, simplifies the staining process by soaking leaf disks, and allows precise quantification comparable to conventional biochemical methods.
application: Suitable for studying starch accumulation in living plant cells, applicable in plant physiology research, and useful for real-time monitoring of starch dynamics during photosynthesis.

Biological materials

1.  Arabidopsis thaliana accession Col-0 (Arabidopsis) (see General Note 1)

# Reagents

1. 99% ethanol (Japan Alcohol Trading Co.)
2. Molecular sieves pack 3A (Wako, catalog number: 131-13531)
3. Fluorescein (Wako, catalog number: 065-00252)
4. Dimethyl sulfoxide (Wako, catalog number: 048-21985)
5. Fluorescein diacetate (FDA) (TCI, catalog number: F0240) (see General Note 2)

# Solutions

1.  Fluorescein staining solution (see Recipes)
2.  FDA staining solution (see Recipes)

# Recipes

1.  Fluorescein staining solution

()

The staining solution should be prepared just before use. Molecular sieves were used as dehumidifiers for 99% ethanol following manufacturer’s instructions.

# 2.  FDA staining solution

()
The staining solution should be prepared just before use.

# Laboratory supplies

1.  Hole puncher 2.0mm in diameter) (Natsume Seisakusho Co., catalog number: KN-291-2)
2. Disposable 10mL syringe and plunger (Terumo, catalog number: SS-10SZ)
3. Slide glass (super frost) (Matsunami Glass, catalog number: S024420)
4.  Cover glass, 20×50mm , thickness 0.16–0.19~mm (No. 1S) Matsunami Glass, catalog number (similar
product): C025501
5.  Microtube, 1.5mL (WATSON, catalog number: 131-7155C)

# Equipment

1.  Confocal microscope (Leica Microsystems, model: Leica TCS SP8X)
2.  Water-immersion lens (Leica Microsystems, model: HC PL APO 63×/1.20 W CORR CS2)

# Software and datasets

1. LAS X (Leica Microsystems)
2. Fiji/ImageJ (https://imagej.net/software/fiji/downloads)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1.1: Use a hole puncher to excise a leaf disk with a diameter of 2.0mm.
hierarchical_protocol.1.1.2: Refer to Figure 1A-B for the hole puncher and excision process.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.1: Add 2-5mL of ultrapure water and the leaf disk to a syringe using a tweezer and insert the plunger.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.2: Deaerate the leaf disk in water by pulling the plunger while holding the top of the syringe.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.3: Repeat the deaeration process several times to adequately deaerate the leaf disk.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2.4: Refer to Figure 1C for the deaeration process.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Transfer the deaerated leaf disk into a 1.5mL microtube with 1mL of 10uM fluorescein solution using a tweezer.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Gently invert the tube several times to immerse the leaf disk.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.3: Refer to Figure 1D for the staining process.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.1: Incubate the leaf disk for 10min with one or two gentle inversions of the tube to sufficiently stain the leaf disk.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Mount the stained leaf disk onto a slide glass without rinsing and cover it with a cover glass.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.3: Ensure the slide glass is moistened with ultrapure water before mounting the leaf disk.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.4: Refer to Figure 1E for the mounting process.

2.title: Observation of Starch Granules using Confocal Microscopy

hierarchical_protocol.2.1.1: Place the slide on the confocal microscope.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1.2: Refer to Table 1 for the confocal microscope settings.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Observe the fluorescein fluorescence using the configured settings.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: The green channel displays the fluorescence of fluorescein-stained starch granules, and the magenta channel displays the fluorescence of chlorophyll.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: Refer to Figure 2 for the confocal images of fluorescein-stained starch granules.

title: Semi-Automated Assessment of LongTerm Olfactory Habituation in Drosophila melanogaster Using the Olfactory Arena
abstract: Long-lasting memories are a core aspect of an animal’s life. Such memories are characterized by unique molecular mechanisms and often unique circuitry, neither of which are completely understood in vivo. The deep knowledge of the identity and connectivity of neurons of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, as well as the sophisticated genetic tools that allow in vivo perturbations and physiology monitoring, make it a remarkably useful organism in which to investigate the molecular mechanisms of long-term memories. In this protocol, we focus on habituation, a nonassociative form of learning, and describe a reliable, semi-automated technique to induce and assess long-term olfactory habituation (LTH) in Drosophila using the olfactory arena, thus providing a method aligned with recent technological progress in behavioral measurement. Prior work has shown that LTH is induced by a 4-day exposure to an odorant and is characterized by a long-lasting (>24h) reduction in behavioral response to the exposed odorant, measured using a manual and skill-intensive Y-maze assay. Here, we present a semi-automated protocol for obtaining quantifiable measures of LTH, at the level of detail required for other investigators in the field. Unlike previously described methods, the protocol presented here provides quantitative and detailed behavioral measurements obtained by video recording that can be shared with the scientific community and allows sophisticated forms of offline analysis. We suggest that this procedure has the potential to advance our understanding of molecular and circuit mechanisms of olfactory habituation, its control via neuromodulation, and its interactions with other forms of memory.
problem: Need for a reliable and efficient method to assess long-term olfactory habituation (LTH) in Drosophila melanogaster. Traditional manual methods like the Y-maze assay are labor-intensive and lack detailed quantitative measurements.
method: Semi-automated technique using the olfactory arena to induce and measure LTH, supported by video recording for detailed behavioral analysis.
innovation: Quantitative and detailed behavioral measurements, semi-automation reducing manual labor, ability to perform offline analysis, and sharing of data with the scientific community.
application: Study of molecular and circuit mechanisms of olfactory habituation in Drosophila melanogaster, investigation of neuromodulation control, and interactions with other memory forms.

# Setting up the olfactory arena

All details for manufacturing the various parts for the olfactory arena and the LED panel were obtained from the Janelia Farm Tech-Transfer office as described by Aso and Rubin 20. Additionally, we developed an odor delivery system where saturated odor vapor can be independently delivered to two diagonally opposing quadrants (Figure 1). Two mass flow controllers ensured a constant flow rate of 100~mL/min in each quadrant. The airflow then converged to a central hole of the arena and was extracted at 400mL/min with a vacuum pump. Odors were delivered to the arena by rapidly diverging the airflow stream to selected odor vials using solenoid valves. Experimenters could choose among three different odors to be delivered on two diagonally opposite quadrants of the arena.

()

Figure 1. Schematic of the odor delivery system. Saturated odor stream, produced by bubbling the air stream through a selected odor vial (e.g., Odor 1) can be independently delivered to two diagonally opposing quadrants. The air stream can be rapidly diverged to odor vials 2 and 3 by simultaneously opening two solenoid valves (V1 and V2 or V1 and V3, respectively). A constant flow rate of 200mL/min on each odor line is ensured by two mass flow controllers. This flow bifurcates prior to entering the arena such that each quadrant receives a constant flow rate of 100mL/min . The airflow then converges to a central hole of the arena and is extracted at 400mL/min with a vacuum pump. Valves are energized using a 12V power supply via CoolDriveSolo valve drivers. Open and close commands are sent from the computer to the valves through an Arduino.

1.  Connect each mass flow controller to solenoid valves (V1) using odor-inert PTFE tubing and connectors, as shown in Figure 2A and B. Push the 1/4" OD (outer diameter) tubing through the push connector of the mass flow controller. Then, using a different diameter straight connector, attach one end of the 1/8" OD tubing to this connector and the other end to the common port of the 3-way valves using the flangeless fittings (Figure 2B).
2.  Connect 3-way solenoid valves and odor vials (odor vial 1). Attach one end of the 1/8" OD PTFE tubing to the normally open port of the 3-way valve using the flangeless fittings and pass the other end of the tubing through the odor bottle screw cap with the insert, making sure the tubing is close to the bottom of the odor vial (Figure 2C). Push a separate piece of tubing through the second screw cap and insert, ensuring the end protrudes slightly from the odor vial lid. Connect the other end of this last tube to the manifold using the flangeless fittings. We obtained similar success using either SCHOTT Duran bottles with lids or scintillation vials with rubber caps as odor vials.
3.  To allow diversion of the air stream to other odor vials, connect the normally closed port of the 3-way valve with two 2-way valves (V2 and V3) by using a T connector to bifurcate the odor stream onto the two 2-way valves (Figure 2D). Connect the 2-way solenoid valves and odor vials (odor vial 2 and 3) as explained above, then connect the output tubing from odor vials with the manifold (Figure 2E). Each manifold can be connected to up to four different odor vials. Use a fitting plug to block the unused manifold port.
4.  Attach the odor inert flexible tubing TYGON SE200 1/16" ID (inside diameter) to the output port of the manifold. Use the luer to thread and the male luer fittings to attach the tubing (Figure 2E). Then, connect the other end of the tubing to two opposing quadrants, first by bifurcating the tubing into two using a Y connector (Figure 2F) and then by attaching each of the two tube ends to the barbed fittings at two diagonally opposite quadrants of the arena (Figure 2K).
5.  Connect the arena’s vacuum fitting and the flow meter using a TYGON SE200 flexible tubing (1/8" ID) and a male barbed fitting (Figure 2G–H), then connect the flow meter to the pump. Finally, direct the pump output to an extractor to prevent odor accumulation in the room.
6.  Cut a piece of red and black hookup wire. Connect one end of each wire to the 12V power supply and the other end to the CoolDriveSolo multi-board (Figure 2I). Make sure there are no exposed wires outside the mount

housing. Insert the CoolDrive valve controller driver on the multi-board (Figure 2J). You will need as many drivers as valves, which means 6 in our case; each board allows independent operation of up to eight solenoid valves. Connect the two wires of the valve to the CoolDriveSolo multi-board. Connect the CoolDriveSolo multi-board to the Arduino via insulated breadboard jumper wires, then plug the Arduino with the computer.

7.  Place a high-resolution camera with a lens above the arena to record behavior and plug it into the computer with a USB 3.0 cable (Figure 2K). A custom-made infra-red LED panel and LED controller, made as described by the Janelia Farm Tech-Transfer office 20, is used as a light source. A desktop Windows PC with at least 8 GB RAM is needed for managing the experimental session and controlling the camera, valves, and LED panel.
8.  The arena and associated odor delivery system should be placed in a climate box covered with a blackout cloth. We highly recommend checking all the connections for potential air leakage before operating the arena for the first time. From our experience, the most common source of air leakage is the Duran bottles used to contain the odors. Ensure that the bottles are evenly closed and use PTFE tread seal tape around the neck of the Duran bottles to avoid air leakage. While checking that connections are tight, make sure that you do not overtighten the connections with the solenoid valves—they are made of soft Teflon and can easily be damaged if overtightened.

()
Figure 2. Odor delivery assembly steps. (A) Add a mass flow controller to the odor delivery system by

pushing one end of the PTFE tubing through the push connector. (B) Connect the mass flow controller with the common port of the 3-way valve, and then connect the normally open port with odor vial 1. Valve wires will be connected to the MultiBoard as described further ahead in panel I. (C) Connection to odor vial #1 is established by passing the tubing through a screw cap and an insert. Make sure the input tubing is close to the bottom of the odor vial. (D) Using three separate pieces of tubing and a T connector, bifurcate the output from the normally closed port of the 3-way valve, and connect them with two 2-way valves. Each of the 2-way valves will then be connected to odor vials #2 and #3 . (E and F) Connect the output from odor vials #1, #2, and #3 to individual ports of the manifold, and then connect the output port with the arena, making sure to use a Y connector to bifurcate the odor flow into two and then connecting each tubing end to diagonally opposed odor inputs in the arena. (G and H) Connect the arena vacuum fitting with a flow meter using a flexible and odorinert piece of tubing, then connect the flow meter output with the vacuum pump using a separate piece of flexible tubing. (I) Plug the 12V power supply wires in the MultiBoard, as well as the two valve wires from each valve. A total of six valves will be connected to the board (two 3-way valves and four 2-way valves). (J) Insert six valve drivers in the board, one for each valve, and then use insulated breadboard jumper wires to connect each driver to the Arduino. You will need an extra wire for ground connection. (K) After assembling the odor delivery, place an LED board below the arena and plug the LED controller for illumination. Insert a high-resolution camera and a lens on top of the arena for video recording.

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Cross 25-30 virgin D. melanogaster females of the desired genotype A with 10-12 males of the desired genotype B 10 days before the experiment.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Prepare at least four bottles containing 40-50mL of fresh fly food for each group and keep all the crosses in an incubator at 25°C, with 60% relative humidity, and a 12/12 h light/dark cycle.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3: Expand the crosses to new bottles every 7 days.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4: Empty the bottles by discarding any adult fly the night before the collection to make sure only newly eclosed flies will be collected the morning after.
hierarchical_protocol.1.5: Anesthetize flies using CO2 and sort between males and females of the desired genotype.
hierarchical_protocol.1.6: Transfer 20-25 newly eclosed flies of either sex to fresh food vials and distribute vials among two groups: Control group, to be mock exposed, and Test group, to be odorant exposed.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Prepare as many 200µL PCR tubes as the total number of fly vials collected.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.1: Add 80µL of paraffin oil (PO) and 20µL of ethyl butyrate (EB) to the PCR tube, to obtain a final concentration of 20% EB.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.2: Alternatively, induce habituation to methyl hexanoate (MH) and add 20µL of MH to 80µL of PO.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2.3: For the control group (mock exposed), prepare PCR tubes containing 100µL of PO.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Mix the odorant by vortexing the PCR tube for 10-15 s at 2,500 rpm.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Cut off the lids of the PCR tubes and cover each of them with cling film squares (1.5×1.5 cm).
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Wrap a piece of copper wire around the PCR tube neck and make a hook with the loose end.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Pierce the cling film with a Microlance needle 2 1×38 mm approximately 10 times to allow the odor vapor to flow out of the vial.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.3: Hang the PCR tube containing the odor inside a fly vial using the copper hook and seal the vial by wrapping parafilm around the cap.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5: Incubate the flies with the odors for four consecutive days.
hierarchical_protocol.2.6: On the late afternoon/evening of the fourth day of odor exposure, transfer the flies onto starvation vials in the absence of odors and incubate overnight in an odor-free incubator at 25°C with 60% humidity and a 12/12h light/dark cycle.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Turn on the temperature of the climate chamber (or any other heating device) to 25°C and allow it to reach the temperature for 1 h before starting the experiment.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Move the fly vials from the incubator to the testing room and let them acclimatize for 30min before starting the experiment.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Pipette 20mL of PO onto six odor vials and label four of them PO and the remaining two EB.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Add 20µL of EB to each EB-odor vial to obtain a final concentration of 1:1,000.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.3: Close the vials and vortex for a few seconds to mix.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4: Ensure the arena is closed before you turn on the vacuum pump and confirm that the airflow is stable at 200mL/min for two opposing quadrants.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5: Turn on the computer and set the infrared light to 25% intensity.
hierarchical_protocol.3.6: Adjust camera settings using the camera software.
hierarchical_protocol.3.8: Direct the airflow to each of the vials for 10 min by toggling the solenoid valves.
hierarchical_protocol.3.9: Transfer approximately 20 flies of the same genotype from a vial into the arena and immediately slide the glass lid to prevent them from escaping.
hierarchical_protocol.3.10.1: Establish a baseline by allowing the airflow to be directed toward two PO-containing bottles for 1 min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.10.2: Stimulate flies with odor in two opposite quadrants of the olfactory arena for 1 min.
hierarchical_protocol.3.10.3: Close the valves to allow airflow from PO-containing bottles in all four quadrants, washing out the odor used in step 2 from the arena.
hierarchical_protocol.3.11: Turn off the pump and carefully collect the flies with an aspirator under red light.
hierarchical_protocol.3.12: Confirm the existence of two output files at the end of a test—a recorded movie and a csv file containing the timestamps and valve status.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Clean the bottom of the chamber, the chamber spacer, and the covering glass with water and 70% ethanol between each run.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Prepare six bottles with 70% ethanol and allow the airflow to go through all bottles for 5min to clean the odor and remaining PO from the delivery system.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Discard the ethanol from the bottles and add water to each of them.
hierarchical_protocol.4.4: Perform another round of cleaning by diverging the airflow to each bottle for 5min.
hierarchical_protocol.4.5: Dry all components with a dry tissue.
hierarchical_protocol.4.6: Turn off the light, the power supply, and the computer.

title: Novel Cross-Species Salivary GlandParasympathetic Neuron Coculture System
abstract: The parasympathetic nervous system is essential for salivary gland development and functionality. Parasympathetic neuron (parasymN) innervation is the main neural network that controls salivary secretion. Therefore, an exclusive model to study parasympathetic neurons and salivary gland tissue circuitry will significantly improve the understanding of the role of parasymN activation on salivary regulation. Harvesting primary rodent parasymNs is challenging due to their body-wide disbursed location. Similarly, the salivary glands are distributed in various locations around and within the oral cavity. Here, we present a coculture model system using human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC)-derived parasymNs and primary mouse von Ebner’s gland cells. We previously reported the first protocol to robustly generate human parasymNs from hPSCs through the Schwann cell precursor (SCP) lineage. The hPSCparasymNs are functional and have been applied to model several autonomic disorders. We also used a Sox10- Cre::tdTomato (hereafter referred to as RFP) reporter mouse line, which labeled von Ebner’s glands, a type of minor salivary gland connected to the trough of circumvallate and foliate taste papillae. This labeling allowed for visualization and efficient isolation of primary tissues in young adult mice (8–10 weeks). By coculturing the two tissues, human parasymNs control mouse salivary gland cell growth and activation. Both parasymNs and primary salivary gland cells can be frozen and stocked at early stages of differentiation and isolation, making applications easier. This novel coculture model system could also be used to model and study related human diseases in the future, such as dry mouth syndrome.
problem: There is a lack of effective models to study the role of parasympathetic neurons (parasymNs) in salivary gland development and functionality, primarily due to the difficulty in harvesting primary rodent parasymNs and salivary gland tissues.
method: A coculture model system using hPSC-derived human parasymNs and primary mouse von Ebner’s gland cells, where hPSC-parasymNs are generated via the Schwann cell precursor lineage, and primary salivary gland cells are isolated using a Sox10-Cre::tdTomato reporter mouse line.
innovation: The integration of human parasymNs and mouse salivary gland cells, the ability to freeze and store both cell types at early stages, and the application of hPSC-derived parasymNs to model autonomic disorders in a controlled experimental system.
application: This system improves understanding of parasymN activation in salivary regulation and can be used to model human diseases such as dry mouth syndrome.

5. Freezer (-20^°C)
6. Refrigerator (2-8^°C)
7. Water bath (37^°C)
8. Centrifuge (Eppendorf)
9. 37^°C incubator with 5%CO_2
10. Class II biological safety hood
11. Lionheart FX microscope (BioTek)

hierarchical_protocol.1.1: Euthanize the 8-week-old Sox10-Cre::RFP mice by placing them in a CO2 chamber and ensure mouse death by cervical dislocation.
hierarchical_protocol.1.2: Place the mouse in the surgical area, wet the mouse head using 70% ethanol, and decapitate the mouse.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.1: Hold the head in one hand and open the mouth cavity by pulling the skin over the skull and below the mandible.
hierarchical_protocol.1.3.2: Cut the corners of the mouth along the cheek using dissecting scissors to further open the oral cavity.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.1: Dissect the tongue with the mandible and remove the skin covering the mandible.
hierarchical_protocol.1.4.2: Transfer the tongue on the mandible to 30mL of fresh sterile DPBS and wash five times using DPBS.
hierarchical_protocol.1.5.1: Inject 0.5mL of the tongue tissue separation solution into the subepithelial space of posterior tongue.
hierarchical_protocol.1.6.1: Dissect the posterior tongue region with RFP+ von Ebner's glands.
hierarchical_protocol.1.6.2: Use small scissors to cut the epithelium of the circumvallate papilla region and peel off the epithelium.
hierarchical_protocol.1.7.1: Dissect and collect 0.1mL of von Ebner's salivary gland tissue under the fluorescent microscope.
hierarchical_protocol.1.7.2: Wash the salivary glands in 15mL of fresh sterile DPBS.
hierarchical_protocol.2.1: Transfer salivary glands into a 35mm dish.
hierarchical_protocol.2.2: Use fine-tip scissors to cut the salivary gland tissues into small pieces.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.1: Incubate the tissue pieces in 3mL of salivary gland cell dissociation solution for 30 minutes at 37°C.
hierarchical_protocol.2.3.2: Gently agitate the tissues every 5 minutes using 1mL pipette tips.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.1: Add 1mL of dissociation termination solution to stop the reaction.
hierarchical_protocol.2.4.2: Centrifuge the cell suspension at 450×g for 10 minutes at 4°C and remove the supernatant.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.1: Repeat the centrifugation step to completely remove the remaining trypsin-EDTA.
hierarchical_protocol.2.5.2: Filter the cells using a 70μm cell strainer, followed by a 35μm cell strainer.
hierarchical_protocol.3.1: Centrifuge the cell suspension at 200×g for 5 minutes.
hierarchical_protocol.3.2: Aspirate the medium and wash cells twice with PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.1: Add prewarmed trypsin-EDTA and incubate for 5 minutes in a 37°C incubator.
hierarchical_protocol.3.3.2: Pipette gently with a P1000 pipette 3–5 times to fully dissociate the cells.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.1: Transfer the trypsin-EDTA and cell solution to a conical tissue culture tube.
hierarchical_protocol.3.4.2: Centrifuge at 200×g for 5 minutes and resuspend the cells with 1mL of salivary gland cell medium.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.1: Count the cells and replate the cells on desired tissue culture plates at 15×10^3/cm^2 density.
hierarchical_protocol.3.5.2: Change the medium the next day and every 2–3 days after.
hierarchical_protocol.4.1: Resuspend 80% confluent and dissociated cells from a 10cm dish into 1mL of salivary gland cell medium with 10% DMSO.
hierarchical_protocol.4.2: Transfer the medium with the cells into a cryogenic tube and freeze at -80°C.
hierarchical_protocol.4.3: Move the vial to a LN tank for long-term storage.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.1: Thaw Geltrex at 4°C overnight and dilute with ice-cold DMEM/F12.
hierarchical_protocol.5.1.2: Coat the plates with Geltrex and incubate at 4°C overnight.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.1: Resuspend dissociated hPSCs in 1mL d0, 1 media.
hierarchical_protocol.5.2.2: Plate hPSCs at 125k cells/cm^2 density and incubate at 37°C.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.1: Fully change the medium with NCC induction, d0, 1 media on day 1.
hierarchical_protocol.5.3.2: Fully change the medium with NCC induction, D2–10 medium on day 2 and every two days after.
hierarchical_protocol.6.1: Aspirate the culture medium and wash cells twice with PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.6.2: Add Accutase and incubate for 20-30 minutes in a 37°C incubator.
hierarchical_protocol.6.3.1: Transfer the Accutase and cell solution to a conical tissue culture tube.
hierarchical_protocol.6.3.2: Centrifuge at 200×g for 5 minutes and resuspend the cells with ice-cold stem cell banker.
hierarchical_protocol.6.4.1: Transfer the cells to cryogenic tubes and freeze at -80°C.
hierarchical_protocol.6.4.2: Move the vial to a LN tank for long-term storage.
hierarchical_protocol.7.1: Aspirate the culture medium and wash cells twice with PBS.
hierarchical_protocol.7.2: Add Accutase and incubate for 20-30 minutes in a 37°C incubator.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.1: Transfer the Accutase and cell solution to a conical tissue culture tube.
hierarchical_protocol.7.3.2: Centrifuge at 200×g for 5 minutes and resuspend the cells with day 10–16 medium.
hierarchical_protocol.7.4.1: Replate the cells on 24-well ultra-low attachment tissue culture plates at 1×10^6/well density.
hierarchical_protocol.7.4.2: Add day 10–16 medium on the next day and feed cells on days 13 and 15.
hierarchical_protocol.8.1: Collect all the SCP spheroids in the culture medium into a conical tissue culture tube.
hierarchical_protocol.8.2: Centrifuge at 200×g for 3 minutes and aspirate the supernatant.
hierarchical_protocol.8.3.1: Add Accutase to the spheroids and incubate for 20-30 minutes in a 37°C incubator.
hierarchical_protocol.8.3.2: Gently pipette the spheroids with a P1000 pipette.
hierarchical_protocol.8.4.1: Replate SCP cells at a density of 1×10^5/cm^2 on top of 80% confluent salivary cells.
hierarchical_protocol.8.4.2: Fully change the medium on the next day and every 2–3 days after.
